Headline: E.ON Can't Fund Endesa Bid With Debt If Tender Rate 100% -4-
Story: E.ON decided to raise its offer for Endesa to EUR38.75 per share in light of developments such as raised longer-term targets at the Spanish company and a new and improved regulatory framework in Endesa's Spanish home market, CEO Bernotat told analysts.   On Jan. 24, Endesa said it expects 2009 earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, to reach EUR8.5 billion, up 2% from its previous goal and well above the EUR7.14 billion estimate for 2006.   Bernotat added that E.ON's initial price was at the lower end of a self imposed range, while the latest offer was nearing the upper end of this range.   "Endesa has delivered in the past months ... Overall we felt we had to revise our offer," because of these developments, Bernotat said.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 09:33 ET (14:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Cycling Into A Big Year For Tech Stocks
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview with Michael Cahill   Managing director and portfolio manager, Chilton Investment Co.     You'd never know the tech sector has been in a slump from looking at the returns of this artful and exacting investor. Since Michael Cahill launched a global technology, telecommunications and media fund for $4.5 billion Manhattan-based Chilton Investment in 2000, he's delivered returns of 119% net of fees, compared with a loss of 45% in the Nasdaq in the same span. Last year, his smart stock picking led to gains of 22.65% after fees. He accomplished that feat with a risk-averse 55% exposure to the market. That's nothing new for Cahill, a veteran of some of the most outstanding investment shops on the Street, including Kingdon Capital, where he customarily turned in triple-digit returns, and Capital Research, where he was a protege of media and entertainment specialist Gordon Crawford. He sees good times ahead and is betting on some powerful themes.     Barron's: The Nasdaq has underperformed for some time, and tech stocks have gotten off to a bad start this year. Is this going to be the year for tech or not?   Cahill: From 2004 through 2006, the Nasdaq has been the single worst-performing major market index. The Nasdaq is up 23% in that time, versus 35% for the S&P 500. The Russell 2000 is up 47%, Japan is up 47%, and European Indexes are up in the mid 60%-range. The MSCI Pacific ex-Japan is up 73%, and the emerging markets are up over 100% during the three-year period.   Despite the performance of the last three years, the earnings growth has actually been pretty strong, and there's been a tremendous amount of cash built on the balance sheets. The data through September puts cash at about 26% of the total assets of the average S&P 500 tech company. The average [Standard & Poor's 500] company has about 8% of its total assets in cash. So tech companies have roughly three times as much cash as the average company.   In the last three years, we've had significant multiple compression at the same time there's been a big buildup of cash, which if you strip it out, makes the valuations even more compelling. That combination is leading to massive amounts of buybacks and buyouts of technology companies by buyout funds or strategic acquisitions of technology companies. There's also been an equity shrink going on, what the Financial Times called a "de-equitization of the public markets." And there's been very limited IPO [initial public offering] activity in the last couple of years.     Q: Put that into perspective, would you?   A: In 1999, there were 282 tech IPOs; in 2000 there were 205; in 2005 there were 23, and in 2006 there were 26. Activity really fell off. So there's been a shrinking of the supply of shares through buybacks, buyouts and strategic acquisitions, often for cash. There's been a limited incoming supply of IPOs. On top of that, there's basically been six years of liquidation in technology mutual funds. Fund flows started to stabilize for the first time in the fall, and while it's a little too early to call that a trend, at least there was some stabilization.     Q: This makes you optimistic?   A: Yes, after three years of underperformance and six years of mutual-fund liquidation. Even a great tech investor like Barron's Roundtable member Art Samberg is pitching cotton futures over technology stocks. A lot of people have just flat out given up on the sector, and they've moved into energy or other areas just when we are about to enter what we consider to be one of the best years for new product cycles. We also expect the continuation of some big themes that started in 2005-'06 but are really going to hit their stride in '07.     Q: What product cycles are you referring to?   A: Prior to this year, we haven't had many really exciting products, and certainly not as many as are coming all in the same year as we have in '07. There have been one-offs like the iPod and Motorola's [ticker: MOT] RAZR. But what will drive this year is Vista, which is Microsoft's [MSFT] new operating system that's been five years in the making. It is late, but from a timing perspective, they are hitting the PC refresh cycle almost perfectly. The last PC refresh cycle peaked around '03. So here we are in '07, and there are 411 million PCs that are 3 1/2 years old or older and that are natural candidates for the Vista upgrade.     Q: But is the refresh cycle still intact?   A: Last year was not a great year for PC sales, and maybe some people held off because of Vista. I think there is some pent-up demand. Another big product cycle is in video-game platforms; we're now entering the third generation with Play-Station 3 from Sony [SNE], Nintendo's [NTDOY] Wii and Microsoft's Xbox 360. That starts a whole new game cycle, which has been a big driver in the past. In 2007, we will also have a new second-generation DVD format with Blu-ray from Sony and HD-DVD from some other manufacturers. These new product cycles could drive some nice incremental demand that we haven't had.     Q: What are the themes you expect to take off this year?   A: Computing and the Internet are on the verge of going mobile, through 3G wireless or through Wi-Fi, where there is a brand new standard called 802.11n, and through WiMAX, which you'll hear a lot more about in the next couple of months. Sprint and Clearwire, which is backed by Craig McCaw, will build out nationwide WiMAX networks. WiMAX is basically a wide area WiFi network. WiFi is mostly in homes or at Starbucks, but WiMAX covers a larger radius and can serve cities. We're just on the cusp of a massive explosion in mobile Internet and computing and adoption taking off.     Q: What's another theme?   A: Another is the continued buildout in the emerging markets in wireless and Internet. India is growing basically at five million subscribers a month. China is booming as well, and many of these emerging economies are just seeing unprecedented levels of demand, and that's good for technology.   Another big trend we see is video-on-demand over the Internet. This is putting a tremendous strain on the backbone, but even more so on what I call the off-ramps, which are the pipes into people's homes. An average e-mail takes up about 10 kilobytes and a five-minute MP3 file is about five megabytes, but a full-length movie is 2.5 gigabytes. So we're moving from e-mail-dominated traffic to the MP3 player, and we are going ultimately to video, and that is going to consume massive amounts of bandwidth. With Google's [GOOG] YouTube acquisition and Ericsson [ERIC] buying Redback Networks, we've witnessed companies positioning themselves for video over Internet.     Q: Any more themes?   A: The last area I'll mention that we as a firm have spent a decent amount of time on is alternative energy. There is going to be a boom in alternative-energy technology, particularly solar. We have worked a lot on the solar industry, because solar is effectively a semiconductor technology that is put to a new use. The same wafers used for semiconductors go into photovoltaic cells.     Q: Let's get down to some picks and start with your mobile Internet theme.   A: We hunted around to find a company that could capture the Internet-going-mobile theme and found a semiconductor company called Anadigics [ANAD]. They're in the sweet spot of 3G cellular, Wi-Fi and WiMAX. They have the reference design wins at Qualcomm [QCOM] for 3G phones and Intel [INTC] for Wi-Fi and WiMAX chip sets. On top of that, they are also a play on video-over-Internet as they make the chips for the video infrastructure for Cisco Systems' [CSCO] Scientific-Atlanta division, and they also make chips that go into the advanced set-top boxes of Motorola.   Anadigics is a small-cap pure play on some of the biggest trends we can find. It has 45.2 million shares outstanding and trades at about $9 a share for about a $400 million market cap. They have got a good balance sheet with a dollar a share of net cash. There is very little Wall Street coverage, which we think is great. We own about 11 1/2% of the company, so we are believers.     Q: What's the earnings outlook?   A: We think they are going to earn close to 50 cents in 2007 and between 90 cents and a $1 a share for 2008 if events play out the way we see them. That's up from break-even in 2006, so they are on the verge of massive earnings acceleration. Anadigics is leveraged to many of the markets that have the most favorable growth prospects. A little more than 60% of all the announced 3G phones are using Anadigics chips. They are winning huge share. The company is also a big play on 802.11n, the new Wi-Fi standard. When we move to the "n" standard, the coverage increases and the speed increases. In '08, the WiMAX stuff will start to kick in.     Q: How much equipment does Anadigics supply to these different products?   A: The beauty of these new standards is it actually doubles and, in certain instances, it quadruples the content Anadigics has in these devices. That's driving tremendous earnings leverage at Anadigics.     Q: Didn't they recently do a shelf filing that upset investors?   A: What that's about is that all their customers are huge companies: Intel, Qualcomm, Motorola, Cisco, Samsung Electronics [005930.Korea] and LG Electronics [066570.Korea]. Cisco and Intel are looking at huge growth prospects, and they are looking at Anadigics as a critical component to that growth. But Anadigics is a company that has got basically $45 million to $50 million of net cash on their balance sheet, so the customers want Anadigics to raise more cash and bolster their balance sheet to ensure they will be able to keep up with the large orders from their big customers.   At some point in the next couple of weeks or months, we will see them come with a share offering to bolster their balance sheet. While people are concerned about the potential share overhang, we've factored the additional share count into our earnings projection.     Q: Where do you see the stock headed?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EON CEO: Endesa Would Manage E.ON South Europe, LatAm Ops -4-
Story: Bernotat added that E.ON's financing strategy for the deal will depend on the final level of acceptances by Endesa shareholders.   E.ON's previous EUR36.5 billion offer for Endesa was financed with a EUR37.1 billion syndicated loan and guarantee facility, the world's largest ever of its kind, signed in October.   Bernotat said E.ON reiterates its previous rating commitment - to keep a single-A credit rating - and may issue equity-linked instruments or equity accounting for up to 10% of the company's share capital. He also reiterated that some asset disposals are possible, and that E.ON is committed to maintain its current dividend policy.   Asked about Acciona's recent statements that Endesa is worth at least EUR45.3 a share, Bernotat said that "those expectations were highly inflated."   Acciona now owns a 21% stake in Endesa, acquired in the open market since September at an average price of over EUR32 each.   Endesa shares closed Friday at EUR39.04. They have more than doubled in price ever since Gas Natural started the bidding battle for Endesa in September 2005 with a cash-and-stock hostile bid of around EUR24 a share at current market prices.   Bernotat said that Gas Natural's pullout of the bidding was, in his view, "the right step."   E.ON launched its first counterbid in February 2006, and later raised its all-cash offer to EUR34.5 a share in September.   Company Web site: http://www.endesa.com   -By David Roman, Dow Jones Newswires, 34 913958125, david.roman@dowjones.com   (Santiago Perez contributed to this article)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 06:12 ET (11:12 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Magnum D'Or Resources, Inc. to be Featured in Investor's Business Daily Newspaper and on Investors.com Website
Story: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.--(BUSINESS WIRE)--February 03, 2007--   Magnum D'Or Resources, Inc. (OTCBB:MDOR - News; the "Company")(website: www.magnumresources.net) updates Investment community.     Information regarding Magnum D'Or Resources, Inc. will appear in the Investor's Business Daily Newspaper in the Corporate News on Monday the 5th, Wednesday the 7th, and Friday the 9th. We will also be featured on Investors.com website under the Corporate News. http://www.investors.com/corporatenews/ .     MDOR was recently covered in the Investor's Business Daily newspaper on Wednesday, January 24, 2007 under the Corporate News (page B11). MDOR was also featured under the Corporate News on the Investors.com website over the past week. Company's management believes, if it is to carry out its policy of openness and transparency, that full and proper exposure by the financial news media is of absolute importance. Accordingly, management remains committed to the Company's policy of openness with the investing community and the financial news media.     Magnum D'Or Resources would also like to provide the investing public with the current share structure which is listed below:    Outstanding: 15,785,090 (Of the outstanding 10,000,000 is Preferred).  Common Restricted: 438,333  Common Free Trading Shares: 5,346,757     Chairman Chad Curtis commented, "I feel as though the key to success for current and future acquisitions with Magnum D'Or Resources is being brutally honest. The management and board of Magnum D'Or Resources, Inc. will help in articulating how the companies will be blended and what role - including limitations - the acquired company's management will play. In the current situation with Terra Elastomer Technologies S.L. they are very well integrated. However such discussions also must go beyond the broad vision for the transaction and include "micro-vision" issues of how the combined business is actually going to be run day to day. Making the right acquisitions, in good times and bad, in my opinion is a principle of discipline. The challenge is to stay focused on transactions that are sought-after and not merely doable."     In furtherance of the Company's objective to become a leader in the Global Waste Management and Tire Recycling industry, MDOR is in the process of acquiring Terra Elastomer Technologies S.L., a company based in Dusseldorf, Germany ("Terra"). Terra, through its subsidiaries, is a manufacturer of granulator and state-of-the-art shredding equipment for use in the recycling industry and also designs and builds recycling and electronic scrap plants under commission from non-affiliated third parties. MDOR expects to continue to grow the Company both internally and through acquisitions. For more information visit the company's website at www.magnumresources.net     "Safe Harbor" Statement under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995:     This release includes forward-looking statements intended to qualify for the safe harbor from liability established by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Headline: Tata Says No Guarantees Over Safety Of Jobs At Corus -FT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Tata Steel (500470.BY), which acquired Corus Group Plc (CGA), will focus on the profitability of the Anglo-Dutch steelmaker's U.K. operations, and there are no guarantees over the safety of Corus jobs, Tata Group Chairman Ratan Tata told the Financial Times, the newspaper reported on its Web site Friday.   "Our plan would be to try to make the U.K. operations more profitable," the head of the Indian conglomerate said.   Tata Group, which also has large businesses in cars, information technology and telecommunications, paid GBP6.7 billion for Corus in a head-to-head auction with Brazil's Companhia Siderugica Nacional this week.   Tata Group would apply to Corus the lessons it had learned from upgrading its 100-year-old Indian plant, which it has transformed into one of the steel industry's highest-margin producers, Tata said, according o the report.   Tata told the FT that the company had so far done only "paper"" due diligence on Corus and had yet to examine the steelmaker's plants in detail. For this reason, he said he couldn't give any guarantee on job cuts, the FT reported. "I wouldn't even attempt to do so because it would be wrong of me to give those assurances or to deny that that was so."   Tata Steel paid what analysts see was a hefty price for the group whose fortunes have only recently turned round, FT reported. Tata's bid of 608 pence a share for Corus, which beat a price from CSN of 603 pence, was 33.6% higher than its original bid.   To make the deal work, Tata Steel will vastly have to improve the efficiency of Corus, whose capacity of about 18 million metric tons a year is more than three times that of the Indian company on a stand-alone basis but whose margins at about 7% are less than a quarter of those of Tata, FT reported.   Tata acknowledged the company had paid "very close" to its top price for Corus, nearly placing management in the position of having to choose between national pride and shareholder value, FT reported.   "We all felt that to lose would go beyond the group and it would be an issue of great disappointment in the country. So on the one hand, you want to do the right thing by your shareholders and on the other hand, you did not want to lose," he said, according to the report.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 01:40 ET (06:40 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ UPDATE: Wal-Mart January Same-Store Sales Gain 2.2%
Story: By Kris Hudson   Of the Wall Street Journal     DALLAS (Dow Jones)--Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) reported a same-store sales gain of 2.2% for January, beating its own conservatively low projection.   Wal-Mart, Bentonville, Ark., had predicted a gain of 1% to 2% for the five-week period ending Feb. 2 over the same period a year earlier. The retailer's January result is the latest in a string of paltry monthly results, including a 1.6% gain in December, a 0.1% decline in November and a 0.5% gain in October.   Same-store sales measure sales gains or losses at stores open for at least a year.   All told, Wal-Mart's latest fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, is shaping up to deliver the giant retailer's lowest same-store sales gain in the 27 years the company has reported such figures. Through December, Wal-Mart was tracking at a 2% gain for the fiscal year.   Same-store sales gauge a retailer's gains or losses against the relatively fixed costs of operating established stores. They are an important indicator of a retailer's return on the money spent on stores, which in turn reflects on overall profitability. Many U.S. retailers plan to divulge their January sales results on Thursday, and Wal-Mart will provide a final, more comprehensive view of its results at that time.   January typically is not a big month for Wal-Mart, accounting for 6.5% of its total sales over the past five years, according to JP Morgan Securities analyst Charles Grom. It is a month in which retailers often attempt to clear out leftover holiday merchandise and reap sales from redemptions of gift cards bought in December. Many Wal-Mart stores last month featured exercise equipment, snacks and drinks for Super Bowl parties and discounted women's apparel from its trendy Metro 7 and George ME lines, which it bet too heavily on last year.   Wal-Mart's weak results in the past year can be traced to a number of factors, many of which analysts do not expect to abate this year. The retailer has blamed its efforts to remodel sections of 1,800 stores this year and last for disrupting shoppers and driving some away. It also has pointed to its need to discount a stockpile of trendy apparel as a hindrance. Perhaps most significantly, the retailer has opened most of its new stores in recent years in urban and suburban markets, where it faces stronger competition and shoppers are not as familiar with nor enamored of its low-price merchandise as are those in its rural strongholds.   Even bullish Wal-Mart analysts predict the retailer's malaise will continue this year due to many of the same factors. At last public notice, Wal-Mart planned to overhaul apparel sections in as many stores this year (451) as it did last year (461). And it plans to overhaul home-décor sections in more stores this year (170) than last (54). While Wal-Mart is nearly done overhauling electronics departments - just 229 this year as opposed to 782 last year - those projects can be done quicker and with less disruption than the apparel and home-décor revamps. Wal-Mart predicts the remodeling projects, once completed, will provide a lasting boost to its sales.   As well, Wal-Mart has broadened its focus to more than just offering shoppers the lowest prices. Its effort last year to lure more trendy, affluent shoppers by airing commercials with lifestyle themes rather than trumpeting low prices yielded uneven results and has been toned down. And the retailer continues to push environmental-sustainability efforts that might boost its image and sales in the long run.   On Thursday, Chief Executive Lee Scott delivered a speech in London about Wal-Mart's environmental initiatives rather than addressing thousands of suppliers gathered in Kansas City, Mo., for the retailer's annual supplier conference. For several suppliers who attended the Kansas City meeting, it marked the first time in their memory that a Wal-Mart CEO did not speak at the event.   As Wal-Mart struggles, some retail observers have separated the giant's results out of their industry predictions to keep it from skewing the tallies. For example, Thomson Financial predicts that the 55 U.S. retailers it tracks will post an average 3.2% gain for January. Factoring out Wal-Mart, that average climbs to 4.4%. Similarly, Retail Metrics LLC, a Swampscott, Mass.-based consulting firm, predicts its pool of 54 retailers will post a 2.8% gain - or 3.6% without Wal-Mart.   Wal-Mart's archrival, Target Corp., which has consistently outpaced Wal-Mart's monthly gains for much of the past two years, anticipates reporting a January gain of 3.5% to 5.5%.   Wal-Mart's report of its January results today marks the final time the retailer will divulge its preliminary monthly results on a Saturday. Beginning with its February results, Wal-Mart will switch to reporting on the first Thursday of the following month along with most other retailers.     -By Kris Hudson, kris.hudson@wsj.com, (214) 755-1794.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 13:02 ET (18:02 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Streetwise: Americans' Foreign Fling
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Lust of all kinds feels right at the time but can get you in trouble. This includes the wanderlust now captivating American investors, as reflected in their ardor for sending their investment dollars abroad.   Since the start of 2005, 85% of all net inflows into stock mutual funds went to international funds, says Citigroup, and last year the percentage going abroad was more than 92%.   The fever has intensified this year. In each of the 22 trading days so far in 2007, the iShares MSCI Emerging Markets exchange-traded fund (ticker: EEM) has seen volume of more than six million shares. In the entire fourth quarter, there were only eight days in which six million shares turned over.   Here we see the same old performance-chasing habit of retail investors. Over the last three years, the rest of the world has delivered nearly double the return of the S&P 500, so the latecomers' dollars flow abroad.   This extreme preference for foreign shares has become a popular PowerPoint slide in presentations of bullish strategists: Investors' distaste for domestic stocks suggests these stocks are under-owned and unduly depressed.   As summed up Friday by Jim Bianco of Bianco Research, "Yesterday the S&P 500 made another new six-plus year high, and the public does not appear to be participating at all. This is bullish!"   But is it that simple? It's not as if investors are averse to stocks, as the big foreign flows suggest. Nor are they shunning higher-risk equities, as the ebullience of the emerging-markets ETF shows. The most that can be said is that the U.S. is relatively out of favor by small investors (as opposed to the pros, who are as a group very much in the market).   The favored upbeat analogy to this setup is the frenzied rush into technology and aggressive-growth funds near the peak of the Nasdaq in late 1999 and early 2000, when nearly all other options were ignored. When the Nasdaq cracked, value stocks and small-caps outperformed for years to come. Note that this rotation required a broad-scale selloff to begin, as most shifts in leadership do.   Yet back then, non-tech and non-mega-cap stocks were rather cheap. In late 1999, the median stock in the 1,700-stock Value Line index fetched 13-times earnings. Today, the median trades for more than 18-times earnings.   If anything, this means big stocks are relatively cheap versus small. There it is again: In a pricey world with few undiscovered opportunities, the only value rests in being cheaper than something that's expensive.     It's tempting to cast the first initial public offering of a U.S. hedge-fund and private-equity firm as a bell being rung at the top of the market and of the "alternative-investments" cult. The temptation should be resisted.   Fortress Investment Group, a manager of $30 billion in buyout, distressed-asset and hedge funds founded in 1998, is poised to gain a market value near $7 billion when its IPO is priced this week.   Have no doubt that the deal will get done within or above the expected $16.50 to $18.50 price range per share, and will then post a strong gain. The firm is only selling a sliver of itself, 8.6%, which would take in $600 million if priced at the mid-point of the anticipated range. With the fine reputation of Fortress' principals and their enviable performance, that amount could be raised among the hedge-fund managers at the Four Seasons hotel bar on 57th Street any given night, before the first round of drinks is finished.   Founder and CEO Wes Edens and four other principals (all between 42 and 51 years old) will retain 77.7% of the economic and voting interest. Nomura Holdings recently paid $888 million, near $16 a share, for a 13.7% interest in the firm, all of which went to the principals.   Conjecture on the Street is that management has teed up a couple of years' worth of strong profit-taking moves in the portfolio to make a strong showing out of the gate. At the aggressive valuation investors will pay, they'd better hope so.   Fortress is looking to get around 20-times earnings, including performance fees. That's close to what the best publicly traded asset managers get for their more predictable management-fee earnings. The likely Fortress valuation embeds faith in the firm's continuing ability to find and exploit ripe opportunities, especially because close details about the hedge-fund's strategies won't be available.   Fortress shares represent a call on the high-liquidity environment and the trend of "impatient capital" engineering buyouts, balance-sheet revamps and other catalyzing moves. At some point, this trend will overheat, and some newly public hedge fund will seem in retrospect to have rung the telltale bell. But it's rarely the first one to market that embodies the fatal excesses.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Dunwoody Max & Erma's Getting a New Look
Story: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- An old neighborhood friend will soon be sporting a new look.     The Max & Erma's restaurant (Nasdaq: MAXE) at 1155 Mount Vernon Highway in Dunwoody will close for a makeover at 10 p.m. on Sunday, Feb. 4. When it reopens at 5 p.m. on Friday, Feb. 9, the restaurant it will sport a totally new look.     "We're going to enhance both the interior and the exterior of the restaurant," said Rob Lindeman, president of Max & Erma's. "We believe our guests will appreciate the new look, which will stress lighter colors and a more open, spacious interior."     The interior decor will still feature walls adorned with the eclectic items that Max & Erma's made famous, but the new design will focus on larger items and less clutter.     The Dunwoody restaurant is the fourth Max & Erma's to be refitted with the new look.     "We're going to escape from the sea of sameness and differentiate Max & Erma's in the casual dining market," Lindeman said. "Many of our competitors have copied our decor and image. We are establishing a new look that reflects our heritage, while separating ourselves from the competition. It will still be the Max & Erma's everyone loves -- great food and service. We're simply creating a new environment in which to enjoy our food."     Lindeman said all of Max & Erma's company and franchise restaurants will be renovated over the next several years. All new restaurants also will have the new look.     The front of the Dunwoody restaurant will be gutted and completely overhauled in about 100 hours. There will be more than 20 contractors working inside and four outside.     "When the restaurant closes Sunday night, we're going to have to be ready to go," said Jeremiah Potter, facilities manager at Max & Erma's. "We're anxious for the Atlanta area to see the new look."          The new design will feature:      - A light, birch-cherry will replace the old mahogany.      - Slate floors will be installed, replacing the wood.      - The brown carpet will be replaced by khaki carpet with purple        highlights.      - Colorful, hand-blown glass fixtures will replace metal fixtures.      - New table tops.      - Completely renovated restrooms.       The new exterior color will be cream with black accents, replacing the old yellow, green and red. The exterior also will have cultured stone, brick and awnings.     Headquartered in Columbus, Ohio, Max & Erma's entered its fourth decade in business in 2003. From a single, neighborhood restaurant that opened in 1972 in the German Village section of Columbus, Max & Erma's operates 100 company- owned and franchise casual dining restaurants. Max & Erma's grew up in the Heartland, but its footprint now extends from the East Coast to Nevada, and Green Bay to Atlanta. Additional information on the company can be found at www.maxandermas.com. Headline: Barron's(2/5) Roll Out The Green Carpet!
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Wall Street has finally placed a welcome mat on the porch of Mohawk Industries, one of America's largest makers of carpeting, and the door looks open for further gains in its stock.   The Calhoun, Ga., company, with a stock-market value of $5.8 billion, has been hurt in the past year by the downturn in housing and high prices for oil, a key raw material for its industry. Mohawk's Big Board-listed shares (ticker: MHK) are down about 6% since the start of 2006. After dipping below 63 late last summer, they've recovered to the mid-80s, rising about 8% last week alone.   Trading at a relatively modest 14 times estimated earnings for this year, the stock could top 100 within a year, bulls figure. There's growing evidence that housing has troughed, and oil prices have pulled back sharply in recent months. As optimism spreads, consumers and companies may soon feel ready to replace their ratty rugs.   Certainly, investors in the carpet industry are in good company. The other giant player, Shaw Industries, is owned by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A and BRK.B). Since investors can't buy Shaw directly, Mohawk is the best way to profit from the dynamics of a leading carpet concern. Mohawk holds about 27% of the $13.9 billion U.S. market for carpets and rugs -- producing enough each year to cover all of Philadelphia and much of its suburbs. Shaw holds 30%, according to Standard & Poor's.   Mohawk, founded in 1878, makes everything from small rugs for dining rooms to vast swaths of wall-to-wall carpeting for corporate offices; it also does a brisk business in floor tiles. Its brands include Karastan, Ralph Lauren, Bigelow, American Olean, Aladdin and Dal-Tile.     Among its fans on Wall Street, the company is known for conservative financial policies and strong distribution capabilities, including more than 20,000 mostly mom-and-pop stores. The CEO, Jeffrey Lorberbaum, has a clear interest in the company's success: His family became the company's largest shareholder in 1995 after Mohawk acquired the Aladdin Mills.   "Management has been around a very long time, and is very shareholder-oriented," says Sabrina Carollo, analyst at Ariel Capital Management, which owns the stock.   Conceivably, the company could be a candidate for a leveraged buyout. It has ample cash flow -- some $800 million in 2005 -- and moderate long-term debt of $2.1 billion. But even without a deal, investors have reason to be optimistic.   Keith Hughes, an analyst at Atlanta-based SunTrust Robinson Humphrey Capital Markets, figures that share purchases are likely in 2007. He's looking for earnings this year of $7.25 a share, up from an estimated $6.27 in 2006; he sees a "worst case" of $6. Assuming the price-earnings multiple returns to 15 times -- about where it was in 2005 -- even the worst-case earnings would leave the stock at $90 a share. Officials at  notoriously cautious Mohawk declined to comment for this article.   The company has been busy diversifying both its product lines and geographic locations. Its most recent acquisition was a Belgian maker of laminate flooring in October 2005 -- its first overseas purchase. Floor tiles provide faster revenue growth than carpets, enjoy higher margins and are less cyclical, according to industry analysts. Mohawk has now established a leading share of the U.S. tile industry.   There were concerns in the market about Mohawk's ability to integrate the European company into its operation. However, the acquisition has gone "much better than expected," says Kevin Cassidy, senior analyst at credit rating agency Moody's Investors Service, which rates the company's debt Baa3, its lowest investment-grade rating. The $2.6 billion buyout was 100% financed by debt so as not to dilute the stock.   But the biggest factor that could fuel the stock's rise is the drop in oil prices. Crude futures lost nearly 7% in January, and more than 30% from an all-time high last summer. Polyurethane, made with oil, is a key component for the foam underneath wall-to-wall carpet. And while the company has been able to pass along the increased costs of raw materials in the past couple of years, thanks to the flooring industry's oligopoly structure, it's doubtful Mohawk will cut prices to reflect the drop in oil prices. Instead, says Cassidy of Moody's, the savings will go to the bottom line.   The end of the pullback in new-home and existing-home sales should also be a boon. Some pros think Mohawk was unfairly punished during the slump. "Wall Street tends to be short-term oriented," says Ariel's Carollo, adding that the stock could be worth up to $120.   With any luck, the shares soon will be the next best thing to Aladdin's magic carpet.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: E.ON Can't Fund Endesa Bid With Debt If Tender Rate 100% -5-
Story: E.ON also reiterated that it expects a successful takeover of Endesa to result in a significant value creation, reaching EUR600 million per year in 2010.   The bulk of this amount, around EUR325 million per year, will  primarily come from a best practice transfer from E.ON to Endesa's Iberian and Latin American operations, Bernotat said.   Best practice transfer from Endesa to E.ON have so far not been assessed, the company said.   Another EUR220 million are expected to be generated through procurement synergies of E.ON and Endesa, he added.   The remaining EUR55 million are expected to come from combining organizational structures in overlapping markets, like Italy, Bernotat said.   However, E.ON called its synergy calculations conservative when compared to other transactions.   E.ON's bid is conditional on getting at least 50.01% of Endesa's share capital and a change of certain bylaws, particularly a cap on voting rights to 10%.   To remove the voting-cap limit, shareholders representing at least 50% plus one share of Endesa must vote in favor.     Company Web sites: http://www.eon.com                      http://www.endesa.com     -By Jan Hromadko, Dow Jones Newswires; +49 69 29 725 503; jan.hromadko@dowjones.com   (David Roman and Santiago Perez in Madrid contributed to this article.)     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 09:34 ET (14:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ: WAL-MART JANUARY SAME-STORE SALES GAIN 2.2%
Story: By Kris Hudson   Of the Wall Street Journal     DALLAS (Dow Jones)--Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) reported a same-store sales gain of 2.2% for January, beating its own conservatively low projection.   Wal-Mart, Bentonville, Ark., had predicted a gain of 1% to 2% for the five-week period ending Feb. 2 over the same period a year earlier. The retailer's January result is the latest in a string of paltry monthly results, including a 1.6% gain in December, a 0.1% decline in November and a 0.5% gain in October.   All told, Wal-Mart's latest fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, is shaping up to deliver the giant retailer's lowest same-store sales gain in the 27 years the company has reported such figures. Through December, Wal-Mart was tracking at a 2% gain for the fiscal year.   Same-store sales gauge a retailer's gains or losses against the relatively fixed costs of operating established stores. They are an important indicator of a retailer's return on the money spent on stores, which in turn reflects on overall profitability. Many U.S. retailers plan to divulge their January sales results on Thursday, and Wal-Mart will provide a final, more comprehensive view of its results at that time.   January typically is not a big month for Wal-Mart, accounting for 6.5% of its total sales over the past five years, according to JP Morgan Securities analyst Charles Grom. It is a month in which retailers often attempt to clear out leftover holiday merchandise and reap sales from redemptions of gift cards bought in December. Many Wal-Mart stores last month featured exercise equipment, snacks and drinks for Super Bowl parties and discounted women's apparel from its trendy Metro 7 and George ME lines, which it bet too heavily on last year.   Wal-Mart's weak results in the past year can be traced to a number of factors, many of which analysts do not expect to abate this year. The retailer has blamed its efforts to remodel sections of 1,800 stores this year and last for disrupting shoppers and driving some away. It also has pointed to its need to discount a stockpile of trendy apparel as a hindrance. Perhaps most significantly, the retailer has opened most of its new stores in recent years in urban and suburban markets, where it faces stronger competition and shoppers are not as familiar with nor enamored of its low-price merchandise as are those in its rural strongholds.   Even bullish Wal-Mart analysts predict the retailer's malaise will continue this year due to many of the same factors. At last public notice, Wal-Mart planned to overhaul apparel sections in as many stores this year (451) as it did last year (461). And it plans to overhaul home-décor sections in more stores this year (170) than last (54). While Wal-Mart is nearly done overhauling electronics departments - just 229 this year as opposed to 782 last year - those projects can be done quicker and with less disruption than the apparel and home-décor revamps. Wal-Mart predicts the remodeling projects, once completed, will provide a lasting boost to its sales.   As well, Wal-Mart has broadened its focus to more than just offering shoppers the lowest prices. Its effort last year to lure more trendy, affluent shoppers by airing commercials with lifestyle themes rather than trumpeting low prices yielded uneven results and has been toned down. And the retailer continues to push environmental-sustainability efforts that might boost its image and sales in the long run.   On Thursday, Chief Executive Lee Scott delivered a speech in London about Wal-Mart's environmental initiatives rather than addressing thousands of suppliers gathered in Kansas City, Mo., for the retailer's annual supplier conference. For several suppliers who attended the Kansas City meeting, it marked the first time in their memory that a Wal-Mart CEO did not speak at the event.   As Wal-Mart struggles, some retail observers have separated the giant's results out of their industry predictions to keep it from skewing the tallies. For example, Thomson Financial predicts that the 55 U.S. retailers it tracks will post an average 3.2% gain for January. Factoring out Wal-Mart, that average climbs to 4.4%. Similarly, Retail Metrics LLC, a Swampscott, Mass.-based consulting firm, predicts its pool of 54 retailers will post a 2.8% gain - or 3.6% without Wal-Mart.   Wal-Mart's archrival, Target Corp., which has consistently outpaced Wal-Mart's monthly gains for much of the past two years, anticipates reporting a January gain of 3.5% to 5.5%.   Wal-Mart's report of its January results today marks the final time the retailer will divulge its preliminary monthly results on a Saturday. Beginning with its February results, Wal-Mart will switch to reporting on the first Thursday of the following month along with most other retailers.     -By Kris Hudson, kris.hudson@wsj.com, (214) 755-1794.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 08:35 ET (13:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Electronic Investor: Putting Yahoo! Into Personal Finance
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kathy Yakal   We're not surprised that it happened -- only that it didn't happen sooner.   Yahoo! Finance (finance.yahoo.com) has expanded its coverage by, at last, adding a personal-finance subsite (finance.yahoo.com/personal-finance). The new section includes nine areas, ranging from banking and budgeting to insurance, retirement and taxes. As expected from Yahoo! (ticker: YHOO), most content comes from external sources, including BusinessWeek, Morningstar and Bankrate.com.  I decided to look mostly at the retirement category since, arguably, that's personal finance's most complex topic and therefore offers a good gauge of a site's capabilities. Basics are covered by a series of articles culled from other sites. While some of this was standard stuff, Yahoo! Finance did a commendable job of addressing issues that haven't yet been beaten into the ground by competing sites. Among the more interesting titles: "Seven Ways to Lobby for a Better 401(k)," "Dealing With an Orphaned 401(k)" and "What to Ask Before Buying an Annuity." Related breaking-news stories are posted, as well as the subsite's most popular articles (not necessarily related to the topic).   Expert opinion at Yahoo! takes the form of commentaries from popular finance commentators like Ben Stein and Suze Orman. Postings on interest rates, Q&As and videos provide added help (however, the relevance of some, like "Davos and Africa," seems tenuous).   Each section also has "how-to" guides. The retirement channel, for example, offers 16 of these personal-finance Baedekers, covering topics like "Choosing Your Annual Withdrawal Rate" and "Maximizing Your Retirement Income." Each is fleshed out nicely with multi-section texts and checklists. Standard calculators are available, too.   We expected to see Yahoo! Billpay prominently featured in the personal-finance section, but oddly enough, you have to go to finance.yahoo.com/bp to get there. That seems like a mistake.   In contrast, MSN Money (moneycentral.msn.com), Yahoo! Finance's most formidable content competitor, highlights its bill-paying ability, which is usually regarded as a vital tool. Click on MSN's banking tab, and a well-designed page lays out all of your options. National interest-rate averages and the bulk of your action items (pay bills, track accounts, find loans) sprawl across the top of the page. Scroll down, and you'll find commentary (such as "Stolen Innocence: Child Identity Theft," from Bankrate.com) and related tools like a debt-evaluation calculator.   So-called decision centers burrow deeper into crucial personal-finance topics, including home-buying, credit ratings and privacy. Like Yahoo!'s how-to guides, these centers consist of articles that address relevant issues and provide needed context on particular subjects.   A lot of this well-written content is exclusive to MSN Money. One example of how it's all packaged: A story entitled "Desperate House Sellers Try New Tricks" is linked to home and foreclosure listings, as well as tools that help you see and compare mortgages, find a loan and get a sneak peek at how nearby houses are selling. MSN Money also has specialized content for taxes and planning, and an account aggregation tool. All are handled as well as the banking section is.   Generally speaking, I preferred MSN Money to Yahoo!, based on both content and ease of use.   AOL (AOL.com) has the advantage of longevity over both MSN Money and Yahoo!, because it started out as a proprietary software program before the Web's rise. In fact, it looks as though the company hasn't purged much personal-finance content since its early days as QuantumLink back in the late 1980s. Whatever information you need likely resides here. Yahoo! Finance pales in comparison.   Content comes both from AOL's staff and external sources, which provide news and commentary, blogs and articles, tools like calculators and online banking, and message boards. I really liked all the help, and I recommend that anyone with financial issues check out the site. That said, it would benefit from some judicious editing to streamline the search process.   I wouldn't consider Kiplinger.com, home to the venerable personal-finance advisory firm's letters, magazine and other content, to be a portal. But it does offer a great deal of its top-notch content free. And the site's editorial scope is at least as broad as that of the typical portal. Still, its depth on given topics doesn't compare to that of others, including Yahoo!'s new site. When we looked, the cover story was on health-care reform, accompanied by a Q&A with the Medicare drug-plan creator. What was there was fine, but we would have liked more.   AP news and other timely content runs across the top of the Kiplinger site and stories stretch down the page, in sections such as "Your Money," "Starting Out" and "Spending Wisely." Like its print work, Kiplinger's content is carefully researched and well-written, and its topics are creative.   Any of the major sites reviewed here will serve you very well, although Kiplinger and Yahoo! won't serve you quite as much.   ---   More on Whispers     In the Jan. 22 Electronic Investor, I mentioned two Websites that report earnings "whisper" numbers. These are estimates gathered from sources beyond Wall Street's equity analysts, whose corporate profit projections are used to form consensus estimates.   I visited the generally available areas of WhisperNumber.com (www.whispernumber.com), which bases its numbers on individual investors' estimates, and didn't see any track record of its estimates, which I regarded as a shortcoming.   In fairness, I should have ventured into the section requiring registration, and I regret not doing so. Although WhisperNumber.com doesn't present its track record in the cumulative fashion I sought (to determine its overall accuracy in projecting profits), it does offer a track record of a different sort, which it argues is more valid.   That record is based on how a stock reacts when its earnings beat or fall short of market expectations, as represented by WhisperNumber.com's figure. It also provides thorough earnings-related data for individual stocks, and academic work in support of its methods. Premium services starting at $24.95 a month go even further.   Whisper numbers can be a good aid in making investment decisions, but I wouldn't recommend using anyone's as your sole criterion for investing.   With that caveat, WhisperNumber.com is certainly worth considering.   -- K.Y.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: EON CEO: Endesa Would Manage E.ON South Europe, LatAm Ops -3-
Story: Bernotat said he anticipates that Spain's stock market regulator CNMV will approve E.ON's revised offer in a few days, and the tender period for the offer will finish late in March. He said Endesa's takeover bidding process should be completed by the first half of April.   Bernotat noted that Endesa's board of directors must now set a date for an extraordinary general meeting to be held before the tender period is over. With Endesa's board scheduled to meet Tuesday, he said that he expects the EGM to be held sometime in March.   Shareholders at the meeting will vote on E.ON's request that Endesa remove its current 10% cap on voting rights, a key condition of its offer. Under Spanish takeover law, Endesa's board must set a date for the EGM at least 30 days in advance.   To remove the voting-cap limit, shareholders representing at least 50% plus one share of Endesa must vote in favor.   Bernotat said he expects the Endesa takeover to be earnings-accretive from the first full year after the deal is completed. The merger would generate EUR600 million in value for the group from 2010, largely due to synergies coming higher efficiency and joint procurement.   Bernotat ruled out staff reductions in Endesa. He also said the company will remain listed in Madrid's stock exchange for the time being. However, he said that E.ON will study a possible delisting of Endesa from the New York Stock Exchange.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 06:09 ET (11:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) A Cool Card Trick
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   When it comes to gifts, America thinks plastic is utterly fantastic. How else to explain the explosion of store gift-cards over the past few holiday seasons? These cards, essentially electronic gift certificates, are well on their way to becoming a $100 billion industry.   One of the top processors of those payments, though little-known now, may soon start to ring Wall Street's bell. It's a unit of Minneapolis-based data processor Ceridian (ticker: CEN), and activist investor William Ackman has it squarely in his sights. Ackman, whose Pershing Square Capital Management  holds 11.3% of Ceridian's stock, is pushing for the company to liberate the unit, Comdata, from its main, less-profitable business -- payroll processing and other human-resource services.   Investors clearly are intrigued: Ceridian's shares have risen about 20%, to 30.67, since Ackman began building his position in November. Some analysts figure that's about all the upside there is, that the shares now reflect the value of both units. But that view probably underestimates both Ackman and the gift-card market.   Ackman's moves tend to pay off big. Although he declined to comment for this story, he has hit doubles and better by pushing for changes at the likes of Wendy's International (WEN) and McDonald's (MCD). Barron's laid out his aggressive ways in a Dec. 5, 2005, cover story, "Meet Mr. Pressure."   His latest quarry, Ceridian, is a data-processing mini-conglomerate with a market value of $4.2 billion. In Ackman's view, as laid out in a recently disclosed letter to Ceridian, the company has failed to realize its potential for more than a decade.   In its main business, it competes with such players as Automatic Data Processing (ADP). Comdata, meanwhile, focuses on two areas of electronic funds-transfer, with more than two-thirds of its revenue coming from systems that let trucking companies track fuel purchases made by drivers across the country. The rest comes from its Stored Value Systems subsidiary, the real treasure: Its card clients range from J.C. Penney and Lowe's to Brooks Brothers and Godiva.   Stored Value specializes in "closed-loop" cards, to be used only at the stores whose names are on them. In the U.S. alone, some $50 billion was loaded onto the cards in 2005, and that should rise to $65 billion by 2009, says market researcher Tim Sloane of Waltham, Mass.-based Mercator Advisory Group. The market should eventually top $100 billion, he figures.   Stored Value and First Data (FDC) are the dominant processors, collectively controlling about 80% of the market, Sloane estimates. Stored Value loaded some $20 billion onto cards in 2005. It earns fees every time a card is loaded and debited, with operating margins of about 30%.   As if that weren't enough, there may be an even bigger opportunity ahead for Comdata in "payroll cards." These are the new Holy Grail in electronic-payment processing, allowing companies to pay employees using plastic. Comdata, on its own, could provide such services, not only for Ceridian but for ADP and other Ceridian competitors.   This nascent industry processed $6.3 billion in payroll payments in 2005, and Mercator's Sloane sees that exploding to $52 billion by 2009. "The market is moving much faster than Comdata," he says.   Ackman evidently has noticed. If Comdata were split off, it might receive more focused attention from management and greater visibility on Wall Street. Although it accounts for just 30% of sales, it's probably worth about as much as the rest of Ceridian, or up to $16 a share, says JPMorgan analyst Tien-tsin Huang. He arrives at that figure by applying industry price-earnings ratios and other valuation metrics to Ceridian's business.   The value to shareholders could rise quickly from that combined $32 a share. For one thing, an acquirer like American Express (AXP) or MasterCard (MA) might snap up Comdata at a premium. And Ackman probably would push for operational improvements at the main, human-resources unit; it now generates 9% margins to ADP's 23%. One way or another, then, shareholders could see at least another 20% gain -- and possibly much more.   Ceridian, which declined to comment for this story, has said it is evaluating a Comdata spinoff. "The logic behind breaking up this company is pretty compelling," says Jefferies & Co. analyst Craig Peckham.   But there could be obstacles. Ceridian CEO Kathryn Marinello's expertise is in payments and trucking, so she may be reluctant to part with the Comdata business in that area. And if Ackman fails in his push for a spinoff, the stock could lose some ground.   Ackman, however, already has assembled an alternative board of directors and looks ready to fight. Mr. Pressure is turning up the heat.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Paying The Piper At Sulphco -2-
Story: In 1998, the federal bankruptcy trustee for the boiler-room A.R. Baron presented the court with embarrassing details of the Wolfsons' relations with A.R. Baron chief executive, Andrew Bressman. According to the trustee's complaint filed in Manhattan bankruptcy court, Abraham, Morris and Aaron invested $400,000 in the brokerage firm after a July 1994 meeting in which Bressman offered to cut them in on his firm's rigged stock offerings. "This was a game," the complaint says Bressman told them, And "in order to make money at the game, you had to be an insider."   According to the complaint, Bressman told the trustee that in 1994 he became close to the Wolfson brothers -- particularly Morris -- visiting with them several times a week and often praying with them. To renovate A.R. Baron's offices, the trustee alleged, Bressman hired a construction company controlled by Morris.   That company, Adonis Construction, got Morris unwanted media attention in 1995 when a tenement it owned in Harlem collapsed and killed three people.     The trustee further alleged that Bressman asked the Wolfsons to let him trade their accounts to help manipulate the price of the "house stocks" that A.R. Baron controlled, and to create the appearance of active trading. How did the Wolfsons get the Baron stocks? Through PIPE deals, of course.   The Wolfsons' accounts "were among the largest and most actively traded at A.R. Baron," said the trustee in a pleading. "The purpose of the trading," the trustee continued, "was to facilitate the A.R. Baron criminal enterprise by creating the false appearance of the firm's liquidity. Unlike other A.R. Baron customers, the firm allowed [the Wolfsons] to move funds in and out of their accounts freely." The small investors snared by the broker's cold callers, in contrast, were never allowed to sell out of A.R. Baron's stocks.   The trustee found that the Wolfson accounts realized over $83 million in cash proceeds from trading A.R. Baron house stocks. Attached to the trustee's complaint were exhibits showing "crossed trades" between various Wolfson family accounts -- trades that the trustee said had "no conceivable investment rationale."   The Wolfsons' spree with A.R. Baron ended after the SEC subpoenaed Morris in the summer of 1995 to testify in its investigation of the boiler-room. The family transferred its shares of A.R. Baron house stocks to Bear Stearns. After A.R. Baron collapsed in June 1996, Bressman pleaded guilty to state charges of grand larceny and racketeering, for schemes that cost investors at least $75 million.   The Wolfsons denied the bankruptcy trustee's allegations that they had been part of the A.R. Baron scam. They objected when the trustee rejected the Wolfsons' claims for more than $1 million from a restitution fund. Eventually, the Wolfsons settled by paying the trustee $90,000.   As strange as the Wolfsons' involvement with a Wall Street low-life like Bressman might seem , even stranger was their use of their charities as investment vehicles in the A.R. Baron machinations.   Among the Wolfson accounts used for A.R. Baron's trading schemes, said the trustee's filings, were those of United Congregations Mesora -- a not-for-profit Jewish organization controlled by Zev Wolfson and his son Abraham -- and the Chana Sasha Foundation, controlled by Morris and Arielle Wolfson. In its tax returns, the Chana Sasha Foundation said it makes educational grants and helps needy families. In SEC filings, it showed a predilection for millions of dollars' worth of the house stocks of A.R. Baron and other boiler-rooms.   As noted, the Wolfson Group's managing director, Eli Levitin, says the family won't discuss its investing. As it turns out, Levitin himself has followed the Wolfsons in patronizing dubious brokers and their stocks. Back in 1997, he received warrants for 15,000 shares of a D.H. Blair-sponsored company that marketed discounted chiropractic care. The warrants were Levitin's compensation for performing investor-relations services, said the SEC filings of the now-vanished company.   In 2004, another failed company in which Levitin was an investor and adviser merged with a videogame-distribution business called Alliance Distributors Holding. The next year an SEC suit alleged that Alliance had been one of several distributors involved in a sales fraud scheme by executives at Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO), publisher of the very violent, very popular gangster game Grand Theft Auto. Without making admissions, Take-Two executives settled the SEC suit, which had contended that in 2000 and 2001, Alliance's predecessor business Corner Distributors had let the Grand Theft publisher park $10 million worth of games. Corner then returned them all after Take Two had falsely reported them as having been sold. (It might amuse Grand Theft Auto devotees to learn that Corner Distributors was involved in a real East Harlem numbers racket that produced a 1998 guilty plea by a patriarch of Corner's family owners.)   Levitin has owned several investment ventures with Mel E. Lifshitz -- a class-action lawyer with the New York firm Bernstein, Liebhard and Lifshitz-and Ezra Y. Birnbaum, a Maserati-driving broker whom the SEC sued in Brooklyn's U.S. district court last year, alleging that Birnbaum allowed his employees at the Brooklyn brokerage firm Pond Equities to engage in "naked" short selling. Birnbaum's brokers allegedly drove down a company's shares by selling them short without borrowing and delivering stock to make the short sales legit.   Neither Birnbaum, nor his attorney, responded to Barron's' inquiries. In a statement to Barron's, Lifshitz said that he and his law partner, Sandy Liebhard, have known Levitin and Birnbaum for more than 30 years. The circle of friends has donated substantial sums to each others' charitable trusts, according to the trusts' tax returns. Those returns also show some of the trusts investing in many of the same crummy stocks as the Wolfsons, through trust accounts at Birnbaum's Pond Equities.   As reported last year by TheStreet.com Website, the Bernstein, Liebhard & Lifshitz lawyers' financial ties to Birnbaum and Levitin raise ethical questions. That's because the lead plaintiffs in many of the law firm's class actions were Levitin's wife, Raizy, as well as Ezra Birnbaum and Birnbaum investment ventures -- including some ventures in which the lawyers themselves were investors.   Class-action law requires an arms-length relationship between plaintiffs and the class attorneys, notes Columbia University law school professor John C. Coffee, to help ensure that the attorneys don't shortchange the class members. "Courts have held that you can't be both the plaintiff and the attorney," says Coffee, speaking generally, "because we want the plaintiff to monitor the attorney, and you can't do that if you're the same person."   Lifshitz and his partners say in their statement that "virtually all" the cases involving Birnbaum or Levitin's wife were started before the lawyers or their charities invested with Levitin or Birnbaum. After TheStreet.com raised questions last year, the lawyers divested themselves of the Birnbaum-managed partnerships that are class-action plaintiffs. They also asked a legal-ethics professor at Hofstra, Roy Simon, to examine the lawyers' investments with Birnbaum. He pronounced them ethical.   The charitable foundation of Lifshitz's law firm continues to invest with Levitin, through a venture called BL Cubed. Within weeks of the Lifshitz firm's sharing in a $3.5 million class-action fee award from suing a company called Irvine Sensors on behalf of Ezra Birnbaum, in June 2004, the BL Cubed venture invested in a PIPE deal in Irvine Sensors (a struggling chipmaker whose shares had fallen 99.7% from their year 2000 high). Then, BL Cubed invested in a SulphCo PIPE deal alongside the Wolfsons. It's strange to see class-action attorneys investing in the sort of companies such attorneys typically sue.   Levitin says that none of his investment activities "relate in any way to, or affect, the Wolfson family, nor do they relate to my position as general counsel of Acta Realty or any other Wolfson family entities."   He says that the Wolfsons' SulphCo position is a long-term investment. It had better be. A few weeks ago, SulphCo's board fired founder Rudolf Gunnerman and filed their Nevada state court allegations that Gunnerman had made many SulphCo stock purchases in violation of the company's insider-trading policy. Former SulphCo employees tell Barron's that Gunnerman frenetically traded the company's stock. Gunnerman remains a SulphCo director and shareholder. He issued a press release calling the board's allegations vicious and false.   Last Monday, SulphCo held a conference call featuring Gunnerman's replacement as CEO -- Larry Ryan, a former General Electric executive. Ryan promised a valid commercial test of the company's oil-processing technique as soon as he could get the SulphCo ultrasound device to function reliably. After the call, SulphCo shares rose 18% to end the week at 3.91.   If Gunnerman's technology does indeed work, SulphCo investors can thank the Wolfsons for financing Gunnerman through PIPE deals. If not, perhaps they can apply for help from the Wolfsons' charities.   ---   Why Hedge Funds Love PIPEs     The histories of wall street's scuzzy companies frequent- ly feature PIPEs, or "private investments in public equities." In these financings, a public company sells stock via a discounted private placement to investors -- typically hedge funds or investment vehicles controlled by wealthy investors like the Wolfsons of New York.   Public investors in PIPE-issuing companies don't make out very well, say researchers like Clemens Sialm, an assistant professor of finance at the University of Michigan's Ross School of Business. Sialm and his colleagues studied more than 5,000 PIPE deals done from 1995 through 2002 and recorded in a database compiled by Sagient Research of San Diego.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Follow-Up: Sign Of The Times: Family Digs In
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The New York Times avoided a possible rebuke to the controlling Sulzberger family when it recently quashed a nonbinding shareholder proposal to end the company's dual-class stock. The action is another sign that the family isn't interested in any changes in the Times' corporate structure, including an outright sale or a family-led leveraged buyout.   The company's stock (ticker: NYT) is down to 24 from a 2002 peak of 52, and its earnings are under pressure. Deterioration at the Times-owned Boston Globe led the company last week to take a big write-down of $814 million of its New England media group, which includes the Globe and the Worcester Telegram & Gazette.   Arguing that the Times has been mismanaged, Morgan Stanley Investment Management, which holds a 7% stake, asked the Times to include in its proxy statement the proposal to end the dual-class stock. The structure lodges control with the Sulzbergers through the company's Class B shares, which account for just 1% of the ownership of the company. The Times nixed the proposal. In apparent retaliation, the family is shifting custody of  most of its assets from Morgan Stanley to another firm.   In a Nov. 13 article,"Ink-Stained Opportunity," with the stock at 24, we argued the Times' assets were worth $35 a share. That calculation still looks good, but it may take time for value to surface as the Sulzbergers dig in their heels.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Paying The Piper At Sulphco -3-
Story: They found that shares of PIPE issuers underperformed those of similar companies by about 30% in the two years after a PIPE deal, if the private-placement investors were mostly hedge funds. A third of the issuers were delisted within two years of their PIPE offerings.   The private-placement investors seem to do well, however. Hedge funds got their PIPE shares at an average discount of 14% to the stock's public- market price, often also receiving warrants convertible into additional stock. Sialm estimates that those warrants boosted the deals' value to the private-placement investors by another 15%. By matching his PIPE database with information in the Lipper TASS hedge-fund database, Sialm figures that hedge funds enjoyed returns of 2% in the month of their PIPE purchases.   Remorseful PIPE issuers have complained that the hedge funds' profits and public's losses in PIPEs result from the private-placement investors exploiting the discount they receive, by shorting the issuers' stocks. Sialm's study found that PIPE issuers' short interest did indeed rise. But he doesn't blame PIPE "privates" for the stocks' declines. "These are companies in poor financial health," he says, that would have gone out of business with or without the PIPE deals. As financings of last resort, the PIPEs forestall bankruptcy.   In the past year, the staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission has sought to get better disclosure in registration statements filed for certain securities that are often sold as PIPEs, says David Lynn, the chief counsel for the commission's corporation finance division, primarily when the deal would significantly dilute the interests of public investors.   -- B.A   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Speaking Of Dividends: Having It Their Way
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Dividends are now on the menu at Burger King Holdings.   Archrival McDonald's has been making payouts since 1976. But Burger King (ticker: BKC), which made its public debut last May, hadn't done so until Tuesday, when it served up a quarterly common payout of 6.25 cents a share. Disbursement will be made March 15 to investors of record Feb. 15. The stock goes ex-dividend Feb. 13.   Most of the distribution ($26 million of $34 million) will go to investment firms Texas Pacific Group, Bain Capital and a unit of  Goldman Sachs (GS). They bought Burger King in 2002; each owns about 25% of the 53-year-old company.   Commenting on the dividend, Chief Executive John W. Chidsey said: "We believe in the company's long-term growth potential and financial strength. This event sends a very strong message. We are clearly on track."   As previously announced, Burger King also retired an additional $25 million in debt Tuesday. Using cash generated from operations, the company has retired $125 million in borrowings during the first seven months of its fiscal 2007 year, which ends June 30. As a result, says chief financial officer Ben K. Wells, Burger King is "now focused on evaluating other initiatives that will contribute to shareholder  value, such as strategic investments, increasing cash dividends and share repurchases."   Traded on the Big Board, the shares, which yield 1.22%, set a 52-week high Jan. 10 of 21.79. Burger King has 136 million common shares outstanding.   McDonald's (MCD) set a 52-week high of 45.06 Jan. 17; it has 1.2 billion shares outstanding, pays an annual dividend of $1 a share and yields 2.24%.   As the No. 2 fast-food chain, Burger King has more than 11,100 restaurants in the U.S. and some 65 other countries. Second fiscal quarter profits surged 41% on robust same-store sales and income from new restaurants. The company credited a big chunk of the gains to its new Breakfast Value Menu, which is being tested in several markets and will debut Feb. 19 with 10 items starting at $1.   Burger King is beefing up its international operations, too. In the past year, it has opened 85 new eateries in Europe, the Middle East and Asia, plus 90 in Latin America. Overall, it expects to open a net 250 new restaurants by the end of 2007, including its first in Japan and Indonesia.   Wall Street is taking notice. "With each passing quarter, we believe skepticism surrounding the company's turnaround plan and their ability to achieve long-term targets lessen," said Lehman Brothers analyst Jeffrey Bernstein in a research note. "In our opinion," said Wachovia Securities analyst Jeffrey Omohundro, "Burger King is not getting enough credit for its superior growth." Citigroup's Glenn Petraglia, however, continues to rate the stock Hold because of the company's "limited track record in the public markets, and the more highly leveraged balance sheet versus its peers."     A sixth annual dividend boost is in the stars for investors in Constellation Energy Group (CEG). The largest wholesale power supplier in the U.S. and the parent of Baltimore Gas & Electric, 101-year-old Constellation Energy Wednesday hiked its quarterly common payout 15%, to 43.5 cents a share from 37.75 cents. Stockholders of record March 12 will receive the dividend April 2, and the ex-date is March 8. Yield: 2.35%. Dividends have been paid without interruption since 1910. The company credited the payout hike to its strong 2006 performance and future growth prospects.   Constellation Energy also posted stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter profits. Along with the sweetened dividend, that sent its stock, which trades on the Big Board, to a 52-week high of 74.28. Considering both share-price appreciation and dividends, shareholder return was nearly 23% in 2006 and 35% in 2005.   A planned merger with FPL Group was called off last year because of regulatory-approval difficulties. Constellation Energy expects to earn $4.30 to $4.65 a share this year, versus 2006's $3.61, and $5.25 to $5.75 in 2008.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Imperial Prepares Bid For Turkey's Tekel - The Times
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- The Board of the British tobacco group Imperial PLC (IMT.LN) has approved a $1 billion bid for Tekel, Turkey's state cigarette company, which has been put up for sale, The Times of London reported Saturday, without quoting sources.   According to the Times, Imperial's board met last Monday to consider an offer and has given chief executive Gareth Davies its permission to proceed.   Turkey's Competition Board approved the privatization of Tekel this month and officials said that the tender could be announced next month, assuming no government opposition, the newspaper reported.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 07:27 ET (12:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
