Headline: E.ON CEO: Endesa Would Manage E.ON South Europe, LatAm Ops -2
Story: Late Friday, E.ON raised its takeover offer for Endesa by more than 12% to about EUR41 billion.   E.ON's sweetened offer - of EUR38.75 for each of Endesa's 1.059 billion outstanding shares - came one day after rival bidder Gas Natural SDG SA (GAS.MC) dropped its own cash-and-shares bid of about EUR24 billion, paving the way for the creation of Europe's largest power company.   Much of the offer's success will now depend on the decision taken by key Endesa shareholders such as Acciona SA (ANA.MC) and savings bank Caja Madrid.   Bernotat said at a press conference that E.ON hasn't talked to either company yet.   Acciona - a Madrid-based construction-to-renewable-energy conglomerate - has previously opposed E.ON's bid. E.ON and Acciona have clashed in U.S. courts, with E.ON claiming that Acciona tried to form a block of Spanish shareholders to prevent the takeover.   A spokeswoman for Acciona reiterated late Friday the company's stance that it prefers that Endesa remains as an independent company, although it would sell its stake if E.ON succeeds in gaining control of Endesa.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 06:00 ET (11:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: 2nd WSJ UPDATE: Wal-Mart January Same-Store Sales Gain 2.2%
Story: By Kris Hudson   Of the Wall Street Journal     DALLAS (Dow Jones)--Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) reported a same-store sales gain of 2.2% for January, beating its own conservatively low projection.   Wal-Mart, Bentonville, Ark., had predicted a gain of 1% to 2% for the five-week period ending Feb. 2 over the same period a year earlier. The retailer's January result is the latest in a string of paltry monthly results, including a 1.6% gain in December, a 0.1% decline in November and a 0.5% gain in October.   All told, Wal-Mart's latest fiscal year, which ended Jan. 31, is shaping up to deliver the giant retailer's lowest annual same-store sales gain in the 27 years the company has reported such figures. Through December, Wal-Mart was tracking at a 2% gain for the fiscal year.   "Overall, while certainly a step in the right direction, particularly in light of the company's management changes a few weeks back and well-documented challenges, Wal-Mart is still not out of the woods, in our view," JP Morgan Securities analyst Charles Grom wrote Saturday in an e-mail. "And (it) will continue to face an uphill battle versus Target and other moderately priced department store chains" such as J.C. Penney Co. Inc. (JCP) and Kohl's Corp. (KSS). Among Wal-Mart's most significant executive shifts in recent weeks was its move of Chief Marketing Officer John Fleming into a top merchandising role.   Same-store sales chart sales trends at stores open for at least a year, providing insight into a retailer's gains or losses against the relatively fixed costs of operating established stores. They are an important indicator of a retailer's return on the money spent on stores, which in turn reflects on overall profitability. Many U.S. retailers plan to divulge their January sales results on Thursday, and Wal-Mart will provide a final, more comprehensive view of its results at that time.   January typically is not a big month for Wal-Mart, accounting for 6.5% of its total sales over the past five years, according to JP Morgan Securities analyst Charles Grom. It is a month in which retailers often attempt to clear out leftover holiday merchandise and reap sales from redemptions of gift cards bought in December.   Many Wal-Mart stores last month prominently featured exercise equipment, snacks and drinks for Super Bowl parties and discounted women's apparel from its trendy Metro 7 and George ME lines, which it bet too heavily on last year. To be sure, while slight at just 2.2%, Wal-Mart's latest monthly gain nonetheless had a high hurdle to clear: In the same period a year ago, the retailer notched a 5% gain.   Wal-Mart's weak results in the past year can be traced to a number of factors, many of which analysts do not expect to abate this year. The retailer has blamed its efforts to remodel sections of 1,800 stores this year and last for disrupting shoppers and driving some away. It also has pointed to its need to discount a stockpile of trendy apparel as a hindrance. Perhaps most significantly, the retailer has opened most of its new stores in recent years in urban and suburban markets, where it faces stronger competition and where shoppers are not as familiar with nor enamored of its low-price merchandise as are those in its rural strongholds.   Even bullish Wal-Mart analysts predict the retailer's malaise will continue this year due to many of the same factors. At last public notice, Wal-Mart planned to overhaul apparel sections in as many stores this year (451) as it did last year (461). And it plans to overhaul home-décor sections in more stores this year (170) than last (54). While Wal-Mart is nearly done overhauling electronics departments - just 229 this year as opposed to 782 last year - those projects can be done quicker and with less disruption than the apparel and home-décor revamps. Wal-Mart predicts the remodeling projects, once completed, will provide a lasting boost to its sales.   As well, Wal-Mart has broadened its focus to more than just offering shoppers the lowest prices. Its effort last year to lure more trendy, affluent shoppers by airing commercials with lifestyle themes rather than trumpeting low prices yielded uneven results and has been toned down. And the retailer continues to push environmental-sustainability efforts that might boost its image and sales, but perhaps not until the campaign endures a while longer.   On Thursday, Chief Executive Lee Scott delivered a speech in London about Wal-Mart's environmental initiatives rather than addressing thousands of suppliers gathered in Kansas City, Mo., for the retailer's annual supplier conference. For several suppliers who attended the Kansas City meeting, it marked the first time in their memory that a Wal-Mart CEO did not speak at the event.   As Wal-Mart struggles, some retail observers have separated the giant's results out of their industry predictions to keep it from skewing the tallies. For example, Thomson Financial predicts that the 55 U.S. retailers it tracks will post an average 3.2% gain for January. Factoring out Wal-Mart, that average climbs to 4.4%. Similarly, Retail Metrics LLC, a Swampscott, Mass.-based consulting firm, predicts its pool of 54 retailers will post a 2.8% gain - or 3.6% without Wal-Mart.   Wal-Mart's archrival, Target Corp., which has consistently outpaced Wal-Mart's monthly gains for much of the past two years, anticipates reporting a January gain of 3.5% to 5.5%.   Wal-Mart's report of its January results Saturday marks the final time the retailer will divulge its preliminary monthly results on a Saturday. Beginning with its February results, Wal-Mart will switch to reporting on the first Thursday of the following month along with most other retailers.     -By Kris Hudson, kris.hudson@wsj.com, (214) 755-1794.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 15:09 ET (20:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Oxlo to Provide Integrations for Microsoft Next Generation DMS
Story: Dealer Management System for Microsoft Dynamics AX (MSDMS) Developed and Marketed Through Infonizer, Will Use the Oxlo Dealer Integration Network for Reliable and Secure Dealer System Integrations       LAS VEGAS, Feb. 3 /PRNewswire/ -- Oxlo Systems Inc., Infonizer North America Inc., and Microsoft, announce an agreement for Oxlo to provide integration services to the Dealer Management System for Microsoft Dynamics AX (MSDMS).     Infonizer and Oxlo are both strategic Microsoft partners including participation in Microsoft's recently announced Automotive Retail Solutions program, with Infonizer developing and marketing the next generation Dealer Management System (DMS) based on Microsoft Dynamics AX, and Oxlo running the leading Dealer Integration Network.     Leveraging the Oxlo Dealer Integration Network will enable MSDMS to quickly integrate with the growing list of Oxlo network members' systems.     "A DMS must be integrated to numerous third party systems, such as OEMs, before entering the market.  By partnering with Oxlo we will accelerate our time to market, as we won't have to wait on integration development," said Richard Ward, President Infonizer NA.  "The Oxlo Dealer Integration Network efficiently provides MSDMS with instant access to leading automaker, lender and other partner systems," added Ward.     John Reed, Director, Automotive Retail Solutions Microsoft, commented, "Microsoft's strategy is to provide a comprehensive modern and scalable dealer solution delivered by an array of integrated partners whose offerings are built on Microsoft core technologies."  Reed added, "The combination of Infonizer's DMS platform and Oxlo's Dealer Integration Network are key components of this strategy."     "Oxlo has dramatically simplified dealer systems integration, allowing dealer system providers to focus on the new technologies and innovation that deliver value to consumers, dealers, automakers and other dealer business partners," said Jim Lejeal, CEO of Oxlo.  "It's exciting to see Microsoft and Infonizer bringing fresh new solutions to the dealer market, and Oxlo is pleased to be working with them," added Lejeal.     MSDMS will capitalize on Microsoft's familiar products and user interface, flattening the learning curve for dealership employees and offers integration across MS products like MS Office and Outlook, and mobile functionality.        ABOUT OXLO SYSTEMS     Oxlo Systems Inc., based in Broomfield, Colorado is the operator of the leading Dealer Integration Network.  Oxlo's network streamlines the shared business processes associated with selling, servicing, and financing vehicles by integrating the software applications of dealers and automakers, as well as other dealer partners such as lenders.  The Oxlo solution enables tighter collaboration between business partners resulting in superior retail performance.  Oxlo's growing network currently includes 5 automakers, 25 dealer system providers representing almost 5,000 dealerships, and a financial network with over 100 lenders.  For more information, please visit www.oxlo.com.  For perspective on emerging trends and issues affecting the market, visit Oxlo Observer at http://oxlo-observer.typepad.com.        ABOUT INFONIZER NORTH AMERICA INC.     Infonizer North America Inc. is a subsidiary of Infonizer ApS (Denmark) and is headquartered in Ann Arbor, Michigan.  The company's focus is on developing and marketing the next generation Dealer Management Solution for North America based on extending the global Infonizer industry builder DMS software platform as well as including strategic partner technologies and solutions.  The automotive solution developed by Infonizer North America will serve the United States, Canadian, and Mexican markets.        ABOUT MICROSOFT     Founded in 1975, Microsoft (Nasdaq: MSFT) is the worldwide leader in software, services and solutions that help people and businesses realize their full potential.    SOURCE  Oxlo Systems Inc.       /CONTACT: Kieran Maloney of Oxlo Systems Inc., +1-303-285-2410, kmaloney@oxlo.com; or Richard Ward of Infonizer North America Inc., +1-734-516-4948, riw@infonizer.com; or John Reed of Microsoft, +1-937-554-0467, jreed@microsoft.com      /Web site: http://oxlo-observer.typepad.com      /Web site: http://www.oxlo.com/     Order free Annual Report for Microsoft Corporation  Visit http://djnewswires.ar.wilink.com/?link=MSFT or call 1-888-301-0513  (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 07:11 ET (12:11 GMT)

Headline: E.ON Can't Fund Endesa Bid With Debt If Tender Rate 100% -3-
Story: In a press conference in Madrid earlier Saturday, E.ON reiterated that the deal would significantly improve the company's leverage, while staying within the limits of the company's rating commitment.   The company also said it still is committed to keep a single-A credit rating.   In order to achieve this, E.ON repeated that it may consider issuing equity-linked instruments or equity accounting for up to 10% of the company's share capital.   At the same time, E.ON also intends to keep its dividend policy unchanged in the wake of the Endesa deal.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 09:29 ET (14:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Tech Trader: The Return Of Michael Dell: No Quick Fix For His Company
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer and Bill Alpert   Investors, after initially bidding up Dell's shares (ticker:Dell) on last week's shakeup, soon came to realize not much would change. The stock eased to 23.50 by week's end -- far from its five-year high of more than 40 just over two years ago.   Over time, however, Michael Dell, as the single leader of the company, could help restore confidence among employees, investors and others. Though often brusque and not particularly well liked within the company, he has alwayscommanded respect as the visionary founder. "That can go a long way to help," says Cindy Shaw, an independent stock analyst. "He faces a host of challenges, but he is tenacious and he has a very good feel for what needs to be done."   As a result of initiatives started when Rollins was CEO and Dell was chairman, revenues and margins are both likely to show some improvement over the coming year, says Citigroup analyst Richard Gardner. He sees the shares climbing to 29, up 23% from now.   But returning the stock to its glory days is something else. "A lot of the problems that Dell is up against," Gardner says, "are secular and industry ones that no one man can fix."   The company has been putting more effort into restoring lagging quality and confidence in its PCs. Though Michael Dell has ruled out the possibility in the short-term, there are indications he may be looking for an operating czar who can help him rework the company's famed direct sales model.   The old model certainly is looking ragged around the edge. It used to be that the company's highly efficient operating methods made it the low cost PC manufacturer and gave it a huge price advantage, but that edge is no longer so clear. Meanwhile, the current growth markets for PCs are in the consumer, rather than corporate, sector, and Dell long has relied on sales to businesses.   With his name above the door, and his fortune in the stock, Michael Dell has every incentive to succeed. But his company's position and the industry's conditions aren't going to make it easy.     The chief executive of Atheros Communications favored Barron's with an update on his wireless data business last week. Craig Barratt's company (ticker: ATHR) bucked the industry last year with 64% growth in its sales of chips for Wi-Fi networking. The company's shares are up about 50% in the last six months, to 24.40 -- valuing the Santa Clara-based firm at $1.3 billion, or about four times 2006 sales and 30 times cash earnings (winking at non-cash charges for stock options and acquisition costs).   Atheros just announced that it will also make Bluetooth wireless chips, in competition with Britain's CSR (CSR.London) and Broadcom (BRCM). Barratt is confident that Atheros will outdo these larger Bluetooth rivals, by selling chips cheaply enough to make the technology part of more cell phones and headsets.   But the Wi-Fi market isn't done evolving, apparently. Barratt said that 23% of his December quarter WiFi revenues were from the latest 802.11n generation of the technology, compared to just 12% of sales in September.   Interestingly, he notes that a growing percentage of his Wi-Fi chips are going into wireless routers sold by telecom carriers like AT&T, as opposed to retailers like Best Buy. The router suppliers to the carriers are companies like 2Wire, while the retail suppliers are firms like Cisco System's Linksys and Netgear (NTGR). The carrier channel got about 25% of Atheros WiFi sales last quarter, says Barratt. He expects that portion to pass 50% by 2008. So Cisco and Netgear better grab share in the carrier channel, before it's too late.     That drama queen of a company Cyberonics knuckled under to dissident shareholders just before its annual meeting last Thursday. The Houston-based maker of neurological implants accepted three directors backed by dissident shareholders like Carl C. Icahn, who owns about 10% of Cyberonics stock (CYBX).   The company has lost its moorings since the forced resignation of hard-charging chief executive Robert P. "Skip" Cummins in November, after Cyberonics started looking into the accounting for Cummins' stock options grants. The Securities and Exchange Commission continues its own investigation of the grants.   For about a decade, Cyberonics has sold a pacemaker-like device whose electrical impulses can reduce seizures in patients who have epilepsy. But Cummins pinned his ambitions on using the device to treat the millions of depressed patients that other treatments haven't helped. In 2005, he persuaded the Food and Drug Administration to approve the depression treatment against the advice of the FDA's own staff scientists, who were not convinced the device worked. Insurers haven't been persuaded to pay for the thing, however, and Cyberonics' lack of sales growth has cut its shares in half since the FDA approval. Friday, they closed at 21.59.   On Jan. 26, a panel of FDA advisors heard an update on a controlled post-marketing study aimed at showing whether the device really works. While Cyberonics says the 460-patient study is "on schedule," doctors have only enrolled 84 patients and performed 51 implants. Twenty-one medical sites declined to join in the study. A second observational study has also had trouble getting doctors to participate: 87 sites turned them down.   The panel also heard about the inconclusive test of another device to treat depression. Neuronetics, of Malvern, Pa., is seeking approval for a non-invasive treatment that sends strong magnetic impulses through a patient's scalp. Researchers reported symptom improvement in 18% of patients treated, compared to 11% who got a sham treatment -- but the difference fell just short of statistical significance and headaches experienced by those getting the real treatment made FDA reviewers question whether the study was successfully double-blinded. The advisory panel declined to take a vote and suggested that Neuronetics do further research.   Cyberonics, meanwhile, has a critical date on Wednesday, when the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services must decide whether the government should pay for that company's depression treatment.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barratt To Buy Wilson Bowden For GBP2.1B -Times Of London
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Wilson Bowden PLC (WLB.LN) has agreed to be bought by Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV.LN) in a GBP2.1 billion deal that will create Britain's biggest house builder, the Times of London reported Saturday, without citing sources.   According to the Times, Barratt is expected to confirm the deal Monday.   The move comes after rival bidders HBOS PLC (HBOS.LN) and Sir Tom Hunter pulled out of the race to buy Wilson Bowden because of a disagreement over what the house builder was worth.   Hunter, who refused to raise his cash offer above GBP21 a share, sent a formal letter withdrawing his bid Friday, the paper reported.   The acquisition means Barratt will leapfrog Persimmon PLC (PSN.LN) as the nation's largest house builder and will bring together Barratt's KingsOak Homes and Barratt Homes with Wilson Bowden's brands including David Wilson Homes, Wilson Bowden developments and Wards Homes.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 06:54 ET (11:54 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Merkel's Govt To Push For Keeping Airbus Jobs In Germany
Story: BERLIN (AP)--Chancellor Angela Merkel's government will push for keeping as many jobs as possible at the half-dozen Airbus factories in Germany, a government spokeswoman said Saturday.   A spokeswoman for the government in Berlin said that fighting to keep as many German jobs as possible amid restructuring at the troubled plane builder was a priority for Merkel.   Thousands of Airbus workers in Germany staged protests Friday over fears that as many as 8,000 jobs could be cut as its parent company, European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co. (5730.FR), seeks to recover after costly delays to the planned A380 superjumbo.   German weekly Der Spiegel said Merkel planned to meet EADS head Louis Gallois to push her nation's cause, before the company's Feb. 20 release of restructuring plans.   The government spokeswoman couldn't comment on the report.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 13:58 ET (18:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Entergy New Orleans Sells Defunct Plant To Miami Developer
Story: NEW ORLEANS (AP)--Entergy New Orleans has sold one of its oldest pieces of property to a Miami developer for $10 million.   The utility told a city council panel last year that Michael Samuel would redevelop the defunct power plant for public use and the land around it for housing.   Samuel declined to comment on his plans until designs were complete. The area that houses the huge brick building has been touted for years for its potential to help revitalize a part of New Orleans near the convention center.   The property was purchased in mid-January in a sale approved by a bankruptcy court judge. Entergy New Orleans has been operating under bankruptcy protection since 2005.   The judge required the money go toward paying down the $50 million Entergy New Orleans owes its parent company, Entergy Corp. (ETR), on a line of credit.   One creditor, the Bank of New York, opposed the sale, saying the property was worth more. But Entergy New Orleans countered that an appraisal put the property at about $8 million.   The president and CEO of Entergy New Orleans called the sale a positive both for the city and his firm.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 14:19 ET (19:19 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(2/3) Redstone Settles Suit With Son Over Family's Fortune
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Matthew Karnitschnig   Hollywood mogul Sumner Redstone, the chairman of both CBS Corp. and Viacom Inc., settled a lawsuit with his estranged son over the family's vast fortune, ending a potentially messy confrontation that threatened to complicate his succession plans.   The terms of the agreement, filed in a court in Maryland where the family business, National Amusements Inc., is incorporated, weren't disclosed. But people close to the matter said the family company repurchased the one-sixth stake held by the son, Brent Redstone.   The sale also consolidates the elder Mr. Redstone's control over the family business. Before the settlement, Sumner Redstone owned two-thirds of National Amusements stock, while his son and daughter, Shari Redstone, shared equal ownership of the other third. Sumner Redstone now owns 80% of National Amusements and his daughter the remaining 20%. It was unclear how much National Amusements paid for the stake. The lawsuit valued the company, which holds a controlling stake in Viacom, CBS and a large cinema chain, at $8 billion.   A spokesman for Sumner Redstone confirmed that a settlement had been reached but said the two sides had agreed to keep the details confidential. A lawyer for Brent Redstone said his client had no comment.   Brent Redstone's suit, in which he alleged that his father led a campaign to "freeze out" his son from the family business, offered a rare glimpse into the difficult personal relationships of one of Hollywood's most powerful men. Sumner Redstone expressed shock at the suit and said it had both pained and angered him.   In his lawsuit, filed last year in the Circuit Court of Maryland for Baltimore, Brent Redstone, 56 years old, sought the dissolution of National Amusements. Brent, a former Boston prosecutor who now lives on a ranch in Colorado, claimed in the suit that he was barred from gaining access to his one-sixth stake and was allowed only to sell it back to his family.   It is unclear what role Shari will play when her father dies. But Sumner Redstone has said he would like his daughter to play a larger role in the company's affairs. She is president of National Amusements and runs the business's movie-theater chain.   Sumner Redstone faces another lawsuit, this one brought by his nephew, Michael, who claims he and other family members were bilked out of their inheritance. National Amusements says the allegations are "baseless."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Paying The Piper At Sulphco
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   The collapse of Sulphco stock in the past year shouldn't merit much attention. After all, lots of hyped tech stocks bomb out. But this little Reno gamble shows the risks of betting on unorthodox science claims -- especially when Wall Street's smart-money investors have gotten there first in private placements.   SulphCo was just a money-losing stock promotion that claimed it could turn sulfurous crude into higher-priced, clean-burning oil. About a year ago, those claims helped boost its shares to $19.70, giving the company a stock-market value of $1 billion. But with just a bit of research, anyone could have figured out that SulphCo's founder, Rudolf W. Gunnerman, had faked his academic background and that his previous tech ventures had cost investors millions of dollars (as Barron's reported in "A Crank Case?" Jan. 23, 2006). Some who'd worked closely with the 78-year-old German emigre say that he'd even claimed to have invented the laser and talked of being "the bastard son of Hitler."   SulphCo (ticker: SUF) now trades at $3.91 after recently falling as low as $2.25, and Gunnerman is in a nasty court fight for control of the company. SulphCo's directors fired him as chief executive at a tumultuous Jan. 12 meeting in which he tried to have the police arrest one of them for trespassing. He's battling the board in a Nevada state court case, where the directors allege that Gunnerman traded on insider information and lied in a recent Internet podcast by saying that SulphCo would become profitable this month.   Small investors eager for alternative-energy plays might have been fooled by Gunnerman's illusionist feints -- like his flaunting "honorary" Ph.D.s from overseas diploma mills when he actually never finished college. Yet it's hard to understand how he might have fooled the savvy hedge funds and sophisticated investors who bet big in SulphCo's private placements of its stock. Unless, that is, they assumed Gunnerman could find them greater fools to buy their shares.   Among the most sophisticated SulphCo investors is the family of Zev W. Wolfson, a New York City real-estate magnate renowned for charity and for active investing in hedge funds. For years, the 77-year-old Wolfson and his sons Abraham and Aaron, and stepson Morris, have invested quietly from their family office in a 29th-floor aerie of their skyscraper at the foot of Manhattan. Just last March, the Wolfsons added to their $17 million investment in SulphCo by putting $2.5 million into a private placement.     The Wolfsons invest widely, but eschew publicity. No wonder. For more than a decade, they've been important financiers of public disasters like SulphCo and of the unsavory brokers who promote such stocks -- underwriting the financial muggings of little old ladies from their glass tower.   Through their lawyer, the Wolfsons declined to discuss with Barron's their involvement with SulphCo or any other investment. The Wolfsons expressed doubts about Barron's journalistic integrity, says Eli Levitin, general counsel and managing director of their investment and real-estate ventures. The Wolfsons are not mere penny-stock investors, says Levitin. "They are really a very substantial family office."   Given their picaresque history on Wall Street's wild side, the Wolfsons might well be concerned about the attentions of a journalist. And that history might make public investors wonder if they want to put their savings into any stock like SulphCo, where private-placement investors like the Wolfsons have shown up first.   Since the early 1990s, the Wolfsons have put tens of millions of dollars into small-cap companies through bridge loans and PIPEs -- private investments in public equities -- a sometimes controversial form of investment that is being scrutinized by the Securities and Exchange Commission.   The typical PIPE deal works out badly for a company's public shareholders, according to most studies. But the deals can produce good returns for the hedge funds and wealthy investors who buy shares in private placements from a public company at a discount that's typically 10% or more from the public market price. That can allow the private PIPE investors to quickly profit through short sales as well as price appreciation. Wolfson family members have been private-placement investors in dozens of companies, including one that federal prosecutors alleged was linked to organized crime.   The Wolfsons may well have been true-believers in stocks like SulphCo, where the promoters hide the truth. Former SulphCo employees tell Barron's that the company secretly doctored crude-oil samples to make its processing seem successful. Through a lawyer, Rudolf Gunnerman denies that his company faked tests or that he ever talked of inventing the laser or being Hitler's son.   For whatever reason, the Wolfsons have repeatedly supplied large amounts of capital to dubious stock promoters. In fact, securities and court filings show that they financed promotions by some of the most notorious boiler-rooms of Wall Street's rapacious 1990s, such as D.H. Blair and A.R. Baron, both brokers that went out of business as the Manhattan district attorney sent their key personnel to prison.   A probe by a federal bankruptcy trustee into the 1996 collapse of A.R. Baron concluded that the Wolfsons were in on the schemes of that brokerage firm, 13 of whose employees ultimately were convicted of defrauding investors.   According to the trustee's 1998 suit in Manhattan's bankruptcy court, the Wolfsons funded A.R. Baron and supplied trading accounts used in the firm's pump-and-dump manipulations, in exchange for a promised share of the illicit spoils. The Wolfsons ended up settling the trustee's proceeding, without admitting to the allegations. They have never been charged with wrongdoing by government regulators. "The action by A.R. Baron's bankruptcy trustee was settled years ago," says Wolfson attorney Levitin, "with a mutual agreement by both parties to dismiss their claims against each other."     After 10 years of patiently piecing together parcels of property at the southern tip of Manhattan, Zev Wolfson launched his realty empire in 1969 when his real-estate partnership built One State Street Plaza, a 32-story building with unequalled views of the Statue of Liberty.   With his real-estate cash, Wolfson became an early investor in the hedge-fund and private-equity industries. In the 1980s, he was a limited partner of money managers like Carl C. Icahn, Saul Steinberg and John A. Mulheren Jr., a controversial trader convicted in 1990 of stock manipulation. That conviction was later reversed, but not before police stopped Mulheren from confronting prosecution witness Ivan Boesky with a rifle.   Wolfson also has a reputation for sharing his profits with charitable beneficiaries, supporting overseas religious and educational groups in a low-profile manner.   In the 1990s, Zev Wolfson's sons began appearing as investors in their own right. While Abraham, Morris and Aaron Wolfson may well have made blue-chip investments that don't fill the public record, numerous SEC registration statements show one or another of them as substantial participants in private placements by a rogues' gallery of bad-news brokers. In addition to D.H. Blair and A.R. Baron, those brokers included Kensington Wells, William Scott & Co. and Patterson Travis. These firms stole hundreds of millions of dollars from the investing public, by the estimate of government regulators.   Executives of both Kensington Wells and Patterson Travis were ultimately convicted of running stock-fraud conspiracies to pump up the prices of, and then dump, stocks like VideoLan Technologies, a Kensington Wells underwriting financed by Abraham and Aaron Wolfson and Morris Wolfson's wife, Arielle.   Morris also invested directly in a boxing promoter underwritten by William Scott & Co., a firm whose brokers were busted in the June 2000 "Mob on Wall Street" dragnet -- when Brooklyn's federal prosecutors and the SEC broke up a ring of boiler-rooms that they said were controlled by New York's organized-crime families.   D.H. Blair was the infamous brokerage firm that hyped many millions of dollars worth of flimsy stocks through the 1980s and '90s, -- until its rip-offs were halted with a wave of regulatory censures and fines in 1998. Prosecutors eventually secured convictions of 12 Blair brokers and four officers for defrauding retail investors.   Zev Wolfson's sons and their investment entities made bridge loans to D.H. Blair's investment-banking clients prior to public offerings. The Wolfsons put more money into PIPE financings once the D.H. Blair stocks came public -- receiving huge piles of stock and warrants that would be ruinously dilutive to public investors once the privately placed securities were registered and eligible for sale.   Patrons like the Wolfsons were essential to D.H. Blair's hustles. Brokers say that the Wolfsons were important enough to rate personal visits from Blair's wealthy owner, J. Morton Davis. A financial analysis of SEC filings shows why.   The Wolfson brothers, in-laws, employees and various investment entities registered shares worth more than $100 million from the private placements of Blair and similar firms.   To be sure, the lists of such boiler-rooms' private patrons were long, and the Wolfsons weren't the only wealthy New Yorkers helping to bankroll dubious stock promotions. Investing alongside them, for example, in Beachport Entertainment  -- one of the allegedly mobbed-up stocks targeted in the June 2000 federal prosecutions in Brooklyn -- was Martin Hodas, who ran many of the peep shows around Times Square before it was Disneyfied.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Bolivian Protesters Force Shutdown Of Natural Gas Pipeline
Story: LA PAZ, Bolivia (AP)--Protesters forced the shutdown of a natural gas pipeline serving several of Bolivia's largest cities to demand that President Evo Morales broaden his petroleum nationalization and expand state energy company operations in southern Bolivia.   Vice President Alvaro Garcia confirmed that protesters  Friday had taken control of a pumping plant outside the city of Camiri, 320 miles southeast of the capital of La Paz, forcing employees of pipeline operator Transredes to shut off the flow of gas.   The pipeline serves La Paz and the eastern city of Santa Cruz, Bolivia's two largest cities, but the shutdown had not affected supplies in either city, Garcia said.   Garcia said the protests have "no justification, because the pipelines are the veins of our country."   Officials at Transredes, a subsidiary of Royal Dutch Shell (RDSB), declined to comment except to say they were monitoring the situation.   The shutdown did not affect pipelines carrying Bolivian natural gas to neighboring Brazil and Argentina.   Since Monday, the protesters have blockaded the main highway outside Camiri to demand that Bolivian state energy company Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales Bolivianos, or YPFB, build a local headquarters in their town.   The office was planned before Morales was inaugurated last year, but scrapped as the beleaguered company reorganizes itself under the terms of his oil and gas nationalization.   Saying that nationalization has not gone far enough, the demonstrators also have demanded that Morales seize two Bolivian oil refineries operated by Brazilian state energy giant Petroleo Brasileiro SA, or Petrobras (PBA) - a move his government announced last September but quickly aborted in the face of fierce international criticism.   The protesters are also seeking the "refounding" of YPFB, which was eviscerated by a botched 1996 privatization. But Morales already declared the company "refounded" last August while announcing plans for a complete overhaul.   "They're asking for the refounding of YPFB, and we're working on it," Morales said earlier Friday.   Morales nationalized Bolivia's extensive natural gas fields last May, sending soldiers to seize foreign companies' installations. But after six months of delicate negotiations the companies were allowed to remain in the country after signing new contracts granting the state a significantly larger share of their revenues.   In the early 20th century, Camiri was home to one of Bolivia's first big gas wells, but production has since moved elsewhere. Local residents hope a new YPFB office could bring much-needed jobs to the area.   Shutting down pipelines is a common form of political protest in Bolivia. Last August, demonstrators briefly shutdown a gas pipeline to Argentina to protest border crossing fees, while in the same month Guarani Indians seized a pipeline control facility to demand a larger share of gas royalties.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:31 ET (05:31 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Cycling Into A Big Year For Tech -2-
Story: A: We estimate the top-line is growing about 30%, and that's well in excess of consensus. Earnings will be going from zero to 50 cents to about a $1 a share in 2008. What multiple do you want to put on that? I think it should be significant. This company is growing very rapidly, and it is not expensive. It is trading at nine times our 2008 number, and earnings are exploding. A multiple in the high teens or even 20 could be possible.     Q: What's next?   A: EchoStar Communications [DISH], which I think is a great play on a possible takeout. The stock is attractive on a fundamental basis at current levels. It is trading at 7.7 times '07 Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] and 6.7 times '08 Ebitda, and the Ebitda should grow at about 18% in '07 and 15% in '08. EchoStar should generate about $2.50 of free cash flow per share in '07. Based on the $40 where it is currently trading, it is at 16 times free cash flow. The company is executing really well; in the September quarter they put up one of the best quarters they've ever delivered.     Q: What about subscriber growth?   A: Their subscriber numbers have been fantastic. They added 295,000 net subscribers in the September quarter, versus 165,000 for DirecTV. The stock should appreciate 20% if it just holds its current multiple over the next 12 months. There is also a lot of additional upside, because we think this is the year AT&T [T] buys EchoStar. It just makes too much sense for the deal not to happen.     Q: Explain.   A: We are really bullish on video over Internet, as I said. This is why AT&T and Verizon [VZ] are deploying their fiber-to-the-home strategies and why the cable companies will ultimately have to upgrade their networks from 750-megahertz systems to one gigahertz.   The problem with the fiber-buildout strategy is that it is slow. While the phone companies are building, the cable companies are taking their telephony subscribers every single day with their triple-play voice, video and broadband offering. Buying EchoStar solves a lot of problems for AT&T. It immediately gives them a fully integrated video offering with scale as they pick up EchoStar's 13 million subscribers.   Remember, AT&T is all about scale. Using a great hybrid strategy of using satellite for broadcast and high-definition channels into the home, they then can use their fiber platform for broadband Internet access. This is critical, because when the world goes to high-definition TV channels, it is unclear what the impact is going to be on the broadband connection, but by leaving high-def channels on the satellite, it frees up the broadband connection so they could potentially have the most superior product offering.   The third point is that AT&T has achieved such massive scale by buying BellSouth that buying EchoStar is no longer a big deal for them. EchoStar has a $17.7 billion market cap. AT&T's market cap is $235 billion. Their enterprise value [market value plus net debt] is $290 billion. They could pay a big premium for EchoStar, and it would barely be dilutive.     Q: And why this year? Because of the more favorable climate in Washington before the next election?   A: Yes. There would not really be any competitive-overlap issues, so there wouldn't be any regulatory hurdles. But, nonetheless, the deal would take probably nine to 12 months to close. If you think about the timing until the next election, they have to do it to ensure that this deal would be announced and closed prior to November 2008.     Q: What could trip it up? There's been talk that the satellite companies might merge, and John Malone is always a threat.   A: John Malone is always a threat. If it could get through the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department, the merger of EchoStar and DirecTV would be one of the best deals ever done. There are so many synergies between the two companies that Malone could pay $80 a share for EchoStar and have the deal still make sense. EchoStar will have about $2.85 billion of Ebitda in '07 and DirecTV will have close to $4 billion, and there is roughly $3 billion in annual synergies by combining the two companies. I'm not sure given the rhetoric out of Washington that it would be a doable deal, although the synergies are so great it is almost worth a shot to try. But the more likely scenario is AT&T buys EchoStar. There are no regulatory hurdles, it is not overly dilutive, and it solves a lot of AT&T's problems.     Q: On to alternative energy.   A: The solar space is an area that is going to be a huge growth industry for many years to come. Yet a constraint on solar's growth is a shortage of polysilicon. Polysilicon is a critical component in solar cells. Polysilicon is also what semiconductor wafers are made of. One of the leading polysilicon producers in the world is MEMC Electronic Materials [WFR]. MEMC has about 230 million shares outstanding. The stock is at $44.70 right now. They haven't reported their fourth-quarter earnings yet, but I estimate they are going to end up earning about $2 a share in 2006, which is up from $1.14 in 2005.   [After our conversation, MEMC reported fourth-quarter earnings of 68 cents a share and 2006 earnings of $2.07, and the stock rose to 52 as a result; we asked Cahill to update his views on MEMC, which follow].   It has about a $12 billion market cap. They have $585 million in cash, or about $2.40 a share in net cash.   We think they are going to earn $3 a share in 2007 and $4 a share in '08. That puts the stock at 17 times '07 earnings and 13 times '08 for a company that is growing 45% in '07 and 33% in '08. MEMC is trading at what we consider to be a very significant discount to both the semiconductor industry as well as its own unbelievable growth rate. That is because historically it has been a company with extreme earnings volatility through up and down cycles.     Q: Where are we in the cycle?   A: The semiconductor industry is going through a bit of an inventory correction, and we think the cycle will trough in the first half of '07. MEMC might finally get some multiple expansion during this inventory correction because it is demonstrating its ability to grow its revenues and margins and earnings through this downturn. It has a lot less cyclicality than it has had historically. In MEMC, we have a company growing its earnings as fast as Google, but trading at 17 times.     Q: How about an emerging-market pick?   A: Sify [SIFY] is a play on the Internet and Internet infrastructure of India. It is a restructuring story. The last couple of quarters have been a little choppy, but beginning in June, they hope to see some acceleration in earnings. That said, they still doubled their Ebitda from '05 to '06. They figured out a long time ago that most people in India don't have a PC, so they built Internet cafes. They have 3,552 Internet cafes. The No. 2 player is Reliance with 240 cafes, and there is no No. 3. Sify has leveraged their Internet cafes to create several portals like SifyMax.com, which is the leading broadband portal in India, and Sify.com, which is an e-commerce and mobile-game portal.   Beyond that, they started building data centers to host their own data, and now they are providing the service to some big companies. They also have 208,000 broadband subscribers. They are one of the largest broadband providers in India, and they do that by working with the cable companies, which are highly fragmented in India. They are getting into travel and have a pact with the Indian railways to sell and distribute tickets through their cafes.   They have also announced a deal with Western Union for money transfers. This is an important service, because very few people in India have credit cards.     Q: What's this mean for the stock?   A: Sify has 42.8 million shares outstanding, and it trades at $7.60. They've got $53 million in cash. They generated $13 million in Ebitda in '06. We think that will increase to around $20 million in '07. It is trading at 13 times '07 enterprise value to Ebitda. This is not something you put all the college savings into. But on a multiyear basis, this could appreciate very, very significantly.     Thanks, Mike.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Chrysler CEO Seeks To Boost Dealer Profitability
Story: By Terry Kosdrosky   OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     LAS VEGAS (Dow Jones)--The chief executive of DaimlerChryler AG's (DCX) Chrysler Group said Saturday that he wants to improve profitability for the auto maker's dealers and that the auto maker will win their trust back by better aligning production with demand.   Chrysler and its dealers were stung last year when inventory bloated and the auto maker didn't cut production fast enough. Chrysler reported a $1.5 billion third-quarter loss and will announce a restructuring plan later this month.   Chrysler, which sells the Chrysler, Jeep and Dodge brands, saw its U.S. sales decline 7% to 2.14 million vehicles in 2006, losing momentum after the company saw a gain in 2005. Chrysler dealers were stuck with cars, trucks and SUVs that sat on lots for a long time, a situation that eats into dealer profits since carrying inventory costs money.   Dealer profitability is important since healthy dealerships are able to invest more in advertising, service and facilities, which helps retain customers and drive sales. Some dealers for the U.S. Big Three have suffered as the auto makers lost market share the past several years to foreign competitors such as Toyota Motor Corp. (TM) and Honda Motor Co. (HMC).   Chief Executive Tom LaSorda, speaking during an interview with journalists on the sidelines of the National Automotive Dealers Association here, said Chrysler dealers "pushed back" when the auto maker tried to push inventory though last year. Chrysler last year also built vehicles without dealer orders.   LaSorda vowed to not repeat those mistakes.   "We won't be in that situation ever again," he said.   He also said that Chrysler will do better at building cars, trucks and SUVs with the right optional features that the market and dealers demand.   LaSorda also said he would keep the sales team structure, with him leading the effort, intact for "probably a couple more months." He said he wouldn't go outside the company for a permanent replacement.   Dealer anger led to the ouster of former Chrysler sales chief Joe Eberhardt in December and LaSorda took ultimate charge of sales and marketing. He's spent a lot of time meeting with dealers trying to improve relations.   LaSorda will be meeting with dealers this weekend at the convention, an annual event that draws thousands of dealers from around the country.   He said the message to them is "trust us, we'll back you guys up."   But he noted that trust will come when Chrysler makes good on its promises over the next few months. Then, dealers can say "they did what they said," LaSorda added.   LaSorda said dealer profitability is still not where it needs to be. While some dealers are doing quite well, others are not and LaSorda said he wants to get them "all back up."   The automaker is also looking for the right balance on incentives so that Chrysler and its dealers make money on car and light truck sales. LaSorda said better balancing production with market demand will help lower incentives.   LaSorda noted that Chrysler got off to a good start in January. Its U.S. sales were up slightly from last year, driven by retail sales, while General Motors Corp. (GM) and Ford Motor Co. (F) saw year-over-year sales declines, including in retail. However, Chrysler's January sales to fleet customers such as car rental companies, which generally are less profitable, were down, as were GM's and Ford's.   Steven Landry, Chrysler vice president of sales and field operations, said during the same interview that fleet sales to car rental companies will be down in 2007 compared with last year, but didn't specify by how much. GM and Ford both said they plan steep cuts in sales to car rental companies in 2007.   LaSorda wouldn't discuss details of the restructuring plan expected to be announced Feb. 14, but said it would be wide-ranging and address every part of the business.   "We're going to do what we need to do," he said.   LaSorda said production at some U.S. plants was down significantly in January, and will be down in February and March, though on a lesser scale than in January.     -By Terry Kosdrosky of Dow Jones Newswires; 313-226-1251; terry.kosdrosky@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 16:42 ET (21:42 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Best Of The Best
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   For some of the mutual-fund world's lesser-known lights, like State Farm Investment Management and GE Asset Management, 2006 was a very good year.   -- That's evident in the results of the most recent Lipper/Barron's Fund Families Survey, which includes a lot of new names at the top of its rankings. In fact, only one firm that was among the top 10 in our one-year returns for 2005 got back to that elite level for 2006. That was Janus, which placed ninth overall, one notch higher than it had a year earlier, boosted by a strong showing in the all-important U.S. general-equity category.   -- The No. 1 slot went to GE Asset Management, whose impressive performance in the 12 months ended Dec. 31 pivoted on a very strong showing in U.S. equities. That catapulted it ahead of behemoths like Fidelity, Vanguard and American Funds. And it marked quite a turnaround for GE, which ranked 62nd in our 2005 survey, near the bottom of the one-year rankings.   -- "Last year, the outperformance was driven more by stock-picking" than by the "sector-type of decisions," says David Carlson, GE Asset Management's chief investment officer for U.S. equities. Making the showing even more impressive: Overall, GE's equity funds were slightly underweight in energy stocks.   -- All the funds in this survey, including a slew of bond offerings, averaged a 12% gain, adjusted for 12b-1 fees in 2006.   As in the sports world, the fund business can be very tough on yesterday's winners. Remember the Chicago White Sox? Such one-year swings are prevalent in mutual-fund land, where a firm's focus and investment bent -- having a large-cap orientation, for example -- can bring divergent results from one year to the next.   Case in point: Pimco/Allianz, which topped last year's one-year ranking, fell to 41st place out of 67, hurt partly by a disappointing showing in taxable bonds, of all categories. The $100 billion Pimco Total Return (ticker: PTTAX), helmed by Barron's Roundtable member Bill Gross, finished in the bottom 15% of its Lipper category.   The returns in our study are asset- weighted. Thus, if a family's biggest funds do well, it boosts the ranking, and vice versa, as was the case with Total Return. This hurt Legg Mason, which slid to No. 23 from fourth in '05, hurt by relative underperformance in some of its largest stock funds. The company ranked 38th in the U.S. general-equity category, which has the largest weighting (51.44%) of the five categories we examine -- the others being mixed equity (14.5%), world equity (16.2%), taxable bond (14.6%) and tax-exempt bond (3.2%).   Among the laggards in the Legg stable last year was Legg Mason Value Trust (LMVTX) -- run by longtime manager Bill Miller -- which placed in the bottom 40% of its Lipper peer group. The strong showing of some of the firm's bond funds, notably those of its Western Asset Management unit, helped offset the equity performance.   Other firms that fell hard included Waddell & Reed, which went from No. 2 last year to No. 30, hurt by a mediocre showing in the general-equity category; and Fidelity, which fell to No. 38 from No. 7, dragged down by poor showings in world equity and mixed equity. Its general equity ranking, 23, wasn't all that bad, considering the widespread impression that some of its largest stock funds, including Fidelity Magellan (FMAGX) need to shape up.   Jennison Dryden also tumbled, to 44th from third a year ago. Going in the opposite direction: J.P. Morgan, which came in 13th, versus 43rd a year ago.   Swings tend to be less drastic in the five- and 10-year results. In the top 10 for both 2005 and 2006, ten-year results include American Funds, Franklin Templeton, T. Rowe Price, Fidelity and Oppenheimer. Similarly, six of the top 10 finishers in the five-year rankings -- Munder Capital, Franklin Templeton, Goldman Sachs, T. Rowe Price, Pimco/Allianz and IXIS -- were there in 2005, too.   Not everyone likes our methodology. Says Robert Flanagan, president of First Investors, "I do not believe it is an accurate way to measure fund performance by ranking funds of all sizes and investment orientations, such as growth and value, together as one broad category." First Investors' fund lineup finished 64th, third from the bottom in the one-year survey -- but it had done much better in other years.   Like it or not, the system does provide a way to look at a fund firm's overall performance versus the competition's. But, as with all such rankings, investors probably should consider it a starting point.   To qualify, a fund group must have at least three funds in Lipper's general U.S. stock category, two taxable bond funds and one each in the world equity, mixed-equity and tax-exempt bond classifications. (For more on the methodology, see box.)(See accompanying illustration -- Barron's February 5, 2007)   Based in Stamford, Conn., GE Asset Management, whose mutual-fund assets as measured by Lipper total $18.2 billion, has more of an institutional than retail bent. "Our roots are more towards the institutional market," says CIO Carlson. The fund operation opened to investors outside GE in 1988. (Its assets, including institutional money, total about $200 billion.)   For non-GE employees, its mutual-fund lineup consists mainly of three families: the GE Funds, GE Institutional Funds, and GE Investments Funds, which are portfolios for variable life and annuities products. The GE Institutional platform caters primarily to defined-contribution plans, such as 401(k)s, and to other institutional investors and certain intermediaries. The Elfun Family of funds is for the most part not open to investors outside of GE.   "GE is often overlooked as an equity and bond manager, but they did well in that regard," says Jeff Tjornehoj, a research analyst at Lipper. The shop also did well over five years, placing 15th out of 62 firms. Even more impressive, it came in third in the 10-year ranking, besting 47 firms.   The fund family's strong one-year showing reflects a balanced performance across the five categories, including a second-place finish in general equity, ninth in mixed equity and eighth in taxable bonds.   Among the stable's strong performers is GE U.S. Equity (GEEQX), which finished in the top quarter of its Lipper peer group last year. Its 2006 return, adjusted for 12b-1 fees (something Lipper does for all of the funds in this survey), was north of 16%, slightly ahead of the Standard & Poor's 500's 15.80%.   The fund's winning picks in '06 included cable operator Comcast (CMCSK); Omnicom Group (OMC), a global advertising and marketing firm; and Cisco Systems (CSCO). With 120 names in its portfolio, the fund wasn't infallible, having missed some of the telecom sector's move last year.   Carlson's outlook for 2007? "More of a flight to quality and a drift to large-caps." He also expects market breadth to narrow, giving big, quality names an edge.   No. 2 was IXIS Asset Management, whose stable includes the Loomis Sayles funds. Standouts in the family include the $8.7 billion Loomis Sayles Bond Fund (LBFAX), which finished at the very top of its Lipper category. Run by Daniel J. Fuss and Kathleen C. Gaffney, the fund looks for securities in a variety of fixed-income sectors.   Last year, says Gaffney, high-yield bonds and currency exposure worked very well for the fund, which notched an adjusted return of 11.27%. In 2007, she observes, "We still think high-yield is attractive, though we see a slowing in the U.S."   Helped by that fund, IXIS finished first in the taxable-bond category.   Gaffney and Fuss don't expect the U.S. economy to fall apart this year. But with junk bonds sporting very tight spreads, compared with better-quality paper, "I wouldn't be allocating blindly to the sector," cautions Gaffney. She also likes the prospects for the investment-grade bonds of homebuilder Lennar (LEN), because "the worst has been priced into the bonds" and "we're not going into recession, and balance sheets are in much better shape than in early '90s, the last housing downturn."   Finishing third overall was RiverSource Investments, which had placed 24th for 2005. The Minneapolis firm had a strong showing across all categories except tax-exempt bonds. "We've been improving track records over the past five years, but there's no question that 2006 was our best year," says William F. "Ted" Truscott, chief investment officer. RiverSource, which as part of Ameriprise Financial was spun out of American Express, had a good showing in the five-year ranking, placing No. 22. But its 10-year ranking was 47th, third from the bottom.   Among its 2006 stars was RiverSource Dividend Opportunity (INUTX), which was helped by telecom holdings, including AT&T (T) and BT Group (BT). The $1.6 billion fund, which formerly focused on utilities, seeks a dividend yield that's 150% of the S&P 500's. "Dividends are becoming more important and in-demand broadly by investors," says Warren Spitz, a senior portfolio manager, adding that demand from the aging baby boomers should provide a nice tailwind for dividend stocks.   The fund, whose adjusted return last year was about 23.5%, finished in the top 10% of its Lipper group.   Coming in fourth was Delaware Management, compared with 41st place a year ago. The firm placed 25th in the five-year ranking and 27th in the 10-year survey.   Helping the one-year results was Delaware Large Cap Value (DELDX), which finished near the top of its Lipper group. With assets of about $1.5 billion, it's fairly concentrated, with each holding accounting for roughly 3% of assets. One of its managers, D. Tysen Nutt, says the fund seeks "to find intrinsic value at a discounted price." Its one-year adjusted return was 23.7%. Aiding its performance: AT&T, Merck (MRK) and Mattel (MAT).   Franklin Templeton finished fifth overall, helped by a 12th-place finish in general equity. Among the big fund family's strong performers was Mutual Beacon (TEBIX), a value fund with an activist bent. Its adjusted return last year was 21%.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Michael Dell Details Corporate Changes In Companywide E-Mail
Story: DALLAS (AP)--Days after returning as Dell Inc.'s (DELL) chief executive officer, Michael Dell told employees of the computer maker he's quashing bonuses for 2006 and reducing managers.   The e-mail sent Friday said the move is to help cut costs and steer the company back toward dominance.   It also revealed that Dell won't hire a chief operating officer, will push faster product development and will expand into new business to drive revenue growth.   Details of the shake-up came after Michael Dell replaced Kevin Rollins as CEO. The change comes as Dell tries to fix mounting problems that include a string of disappointing earnings, eroding market share and an ongoing federal accounting probe.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 12:51 ET (17:51 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) European Trader: Ericsson's Undue Pounding
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Arindam Nag   The rush to sell shares of LM Ericsson is a reminder of how sensitive investors are to mild earnings disappointment and sober forecasts, particularly in a sector as badly wracked by price competition as telecom equipment.   The Swedish concern's American despositary receipts (ticker: ERIC) plunged more than 6% early Friday, to 36.80, after the company reported a 14% earnings gain for the fourth quarter and lowered its targets for 2007.   But the months ahead maymake the selloff look like at least a partial overreaction. After all, if you're confident that investing in an equipment supplier is the way the play booming global demand for mobile and broadband, Ericsson is a relatively risk-free way to do it.   Ericsson has stolen a march over its rivals in the industry-consolidation stakes. The Marconi acquisition under its belt and December's purchase of Redback Networks both look to be proceeding well. In contrast, Alcatel-Lucent (ALU) is a messy work in progress. The venture between Nokia (NOK) and Siemens (SI) is delayed.   An ever more leanly managed Ericsson generated more cash than expected in 2006, which ought to help it handle the above-average growth it expects in 2007, even if the industry as whole won't expand as fast as Ericsson was hoping.   Slippage in profit margins is easily attributed to an expansion of services activities that promise more durable, if less lucrative, sales growth. Costs associated with rolling out networks at Ericsson's pace inevitably weighs on profitability in the short term. Even so, Ericsson's margins remain far above peers'.   Ericsson has been gaining in share of the wireless market, with its dominance of the so-called WCDMA standard. On the handset front, the Sony-Ericsson venture has been positioning itself at the premium, music-playing end of the market, which looks savvy for now. It's certainly in better shape than Motorola (MOT), whose RAZR phone appears to have lost its magic.     Anyone sizing up Deutsche Bank as a long-term bet in the banking sector should take a good look at a part of its business that generates few headlines.   The German bank's (DB) Global Transactions business, which offers cash management for corporations, securities services, trade finance and more, is in the third year of a robust recovery, boasting a 66% return on equity at the end of 2006. That's the highest among all the bank's business units.   It's tempting to focus instead on Deutsche Bank's investment- banking business. For it was hefty gains from proprietary trading and some one-offs that propelled Deutsche Bank's fourth-quarter earnings to the top end of analysts' expectations. Net income for the period more than doubled, to a record 1.81 billion euros ($2.35 billion).   But the proprietary-trading profits are notoriously unpredictable. Global Transactions is usually less volatile, given its strong correlation with GDP growth and increases in international trade.   Though the bank's pretax profit has risen an average 30% in the past three years, Global Transactions' profit has grown three times as fast. In 2006, it jumped 38%, ahead of the bank's overall profit of 28%.   ---   Matthew Curtin and Arindam Nag are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                             DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Country  Region/    DJ Global            DJ Global          DJ Global     Point     Indexes,             Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
