Headline: Johnson Eyes Deal For Fish Works - The Times
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)-- Luke Johnson, the chairman of U.K. broadcaster Channel 4, is considering making an offer for FishWorks PLC (FSH.LN), the troubled AIM-listed restaurant operator, through his Risk Capital Partners private equity vehicle, The Times of London reported Saturday without quoting sources.   According to the Times, the entrepreneur is understood to have put together a consortium of investors and may already have made a preliminary approach to the board of Fish Works.   Shares in Fish Works, which floated at 33 pence in June 2005, fell sharply this week to a low of 10 pence after the company said it was in talks with its bankers over its financial position, the newspaper reported.   Shares rose Friday to add 1/2 pence to 13 1/2 pence amid rumours of bid interest. According to a stated understanding by the Times, any bid by Risk Capital Partners is likely to be below the current price. Risk declined to comment.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 07:56 ET (12:56 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     Cerus   -- CERS-NNM   Outperform/Speculative Risk     -- Price 5.42 on Jan. 26   by Baird Securities     Germany has approved sale of Cerus' Intercept platelet system . . . almost two quarters earlier than we'd anticipated. . . . While revenues should accrue for Intercept platelets in Europe, [the Concord, Calif.-based] Cerus also has it in late stages of clinical development in the U.S. While we are generally skeptical of cancer vaccines, Cerus' efforts represent a new way of developing therapies in this space. . . . Our 12-month target is $12, derive[d] by applying a 25 multiple to our 2010 earnings-per-share estimate of 96 cents, discounted back by 25% per year. . . . Valuation is heavily dependent upon Intercept uptake in both Europe and the U.S.     Countrywide Financial   -- CFC-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 43.38 on Jan. 30   by Friedman Billings Ramsey     CFC reported 4Q06 EPS of $1.01, below the Street's estimate of $1.03 and above our estimate of 96 cents . . . Maintaining price target of 45, which reflects 10 times our FY07 EPS estimate. . . . We do not believe CFC is for sale at this time; however, an alliance with Bank of America looks reasonable and attractive. . . . Downgrading CFC to Market Perform from Outperform to reflect a fairly valued stock price, given a tough market environment; lowering our fiscal '07 EPS estimate from $4.50 to $4.40.     Getty Images   -- GYI-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 44.44 on Jan. 30   by McAdams Wright Ragen     Getty reported 4Q earnings of approximately 60 cents per share, after stripping out a one-time charge and normalizing tax rate. We had been looking for 57 cents and consensus was 56 cents . . . GYI posted 4Q sales of $203.5 million versus consensus estimate $196 million . . . [an] increase of 9.5% year-over-year (6.5% currency-neutral). . . . Getty reaffirmed '07 revenue guidance of mid-single digit growth and earnings of 1.5 times revenue growth. We believe the table may be set for GYI to exceed those expectations . . . We view the shares as appropriate for accounts capable of accommodating above-average volatility.     INVESTools   -- IEDU-NNM     Buy   -- Price 13.69 on Jan. 29   by Merriman Curhan Ford     Once the acquisition [of the online-broker thinkorswim] closes, the combined company should have a nearly $1 billion enterprise value, show expanding margins and accelerating trends in the TOS division . . . Our expectations for 4Q06 and FY07 have not changed, although we believe that our FY07 estimates are conservative with 15% sales growth and flat adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization [Ebitda] margin (21%) assumptions. We believe 1Q07 is shaping up very strong.     Labor Ready   -- LRW-NYSE     Market Perform   -- Price 18.50 on Jan. 29   by JMP Securities     Reducing our rating from Market Outperform to Market Perform and lowering estimates. Since LRW reported a disappointing outlook after 3Q earnings, the stock has moved up in excess of 15%. We expect the next few quarters to be quite challenging, as we believe the housing market has yet to find a bottom; it's now apparent that services tangentially related to residential construction are being significantly impacted and comprise a much larger percentage of revenue for LRW than we originally thought . . . We are slightly lowering our 4Q06 EPS estimate from 30 cents to 29 cents and reducing FY07 EPS estimate from $1.42 to $1.32.     LaSalle Hotel Properties   -- LHO-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 46.95 on Jan. 30   by Wachovia Securities     Reiterating Outperform. This lodging real-estate investment trust [owns] higher-end, full-service hotels located in convention, resort, and major urban markets, with significant exposure to Washington, Chicago, New York, Boston, San Diego, Seattle, and Hollywood. LHO's portfolio of 32 properties features Westin, Hyatt, Hilton, Marriott, Sheraton, and independent brands; 2007 Ebitda is expected to be in the range of $208.9 million to $212.1 million with [funds-from-operations] per share between $3.10 and $3.18, excluding noncash expense from redemption of preferred shares and asset-sale proceeds. While the near-term disruption from renovations impact earnings estimates in 2007, it does not negatively impact net asset value, in our view.     Mattel   -- MAT-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 23.97 on Jan. 30   by Wedbush Morgan     Q4 beats expectations with broad product strength; maintaining Buy and increasing target from 26 to 28. Q4 EPS of 75 cents compares to 58 cents a year ago.   Barbie posted [her] fourth consecutive increase in U.S. shipments, although the 3% gain was slightly below that in Q3 and below the 5% increase we had expected. Most other product categories were up, including Fisher-Price, non-Barbie dolls, and Entertainment/Games. The balance sheet continues to be in great shape, in our opinion. Raising 2007 revenue estimate from $5.8 billion to $5.96 billion and EPS forecast from $1.50 to $1.60; increasing 2008 revenue projection from $6.02 billion to $6.31 billion and EPS estimate from $1.65 to $1.80.     Moog   -- MOG/A-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 39.05 on Jan. 30   by Benchmark     [Moog designs and makes precision-motion and fluid-control systems for aerospace, defense, industrial and medical-device markets.] Moog reported F1Q07 EPS of 56 cents on revenue of $356 million, versus our estimates of 51 cents on revenue of $338.2 million compared to the consensus of 51 cents on $339.6 million [in revenue]. Performance was strong in every one of Moog's business segments; in fact most were above our expectations, reflecting strong demand in corresponding end markets.     Pier 1   -- PIR-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 6.60 on Jan. 30   by Kevin Dann & Partners     Pier 1 Imports named Alex Smith as the company's new president and CEO, effective Feb. 19 . . . Tom Thomas will replace [Marvin] Girouard as a nonexecutive Chairman of the Board. . . . Smith will be on a short leash with investors as they look for clarity in the company's turn-around program . . . To Smith's benefit, he will be coming on board at a time when the company's sales are at their worst. . . .   We believe that investors should continue to maintain their positions in PIR shares. However, we would not recommend new investment in the company, as the level of uncertainties outweighs the potential benefits . . . The company also has to re-establish its product-differentiation strategy, which is vital to restoring product margins that are below historic levels for Pier 1. As such, we maintain our Hold rating.     Provident New York Bancorp   -- PBNY-NNM     Underperform   -- Price 14.80 on Jan. 30   by Ryan Beck     PBNY reported 1Q07 earnings of 11 cents per diluted share, down 8% from the 12 cents reported in 1Q06 and one cent below our estimate. . . . Anticipating dislocations stemming from JPMorgan's purchase of 338 branches from Bank of New York, PBNY launched several [certificate of deposit] promotions that contributed to an 18-basis-point serial-quarter compression in margin . . . we're lowering this year's EPS estimate from 53 cents to 45 cents. Our F08 estimate is 58 cents. . . . we think the stock remains fully valued.     Tesoro Petroleum   -- TSO-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 78.55 on Jan. 30   by Bear Stearns     Ugrading our rating from Peer Perform to Outperform. We believe the acquisition of Royal Dutch Shell's 100,000 [barrel/day] Wilmington, Calif. [refinery] could lead to upside in the stock, based on our assessment of added earnings power, and through potential multiple expansion, reflecting an overall higher-quality asset base . . . We believe the economics of the deal are attractive, and estimate it will be accretive to '07 and '08 earnings and cash flow, based on our refining-margin assumptions. We have raised our 2007 EPS estimate from $6 per share to $7 and our 2007 cash flow estimate to $11 per share from $10.     Weatherford Int'l.   -- WFT-NYSE     Hold   -- Price 37.74 on Jan. 30   by Sterne Agee     Weatherford [a provider of equipment and services to oil- and gas-well drillers] reported 4Q06 diluted operating EPS of 76 cents versus 46 cents in 4Q05, a gain of 65%; consensus and our estimate was 74 cents; total EPS was 78 cents. Maintaining Hold rating and confirming target price of 42, which equates to 12.7 times and 6.3 times our 2007 estimated EPS and Ebitda outlook, respectively. Our EPS estimate for 2007 has been slightly lowered, by six cents to $3.32, versus $2.53 in 2006, a gain of 31%. Our 1Q07 estimate has been slightly lowered by 1 cent to 80 cents, versus 57 cents in 4Q06, a gain of 41%.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) The Striking Price: Betting Against Dell
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   The word out of Round Rock, Texas, was "Dude, you're getting a Dell -- as CEO."   Options traders, however, let fly a resounding "so what?" to the news that Michael Dell had removed his protege and would become CEO of a company struggling to remedy big operational missteps.   Many traders sold bullish calls to bet against Dell's turnaround, even as the stock initially rallied higher on expectations that Mr. Dell can repair a once highly regarded business model that many investors now perceive as broken.   On the day the news was released, more than 56,000 Dell calls traded, including many sales in anticipation that the worst was yet to come. The options contracts represented a fraction of the stock volume on a day when more than 87 million shares traded, but the options trading underscores the skepticism of some of the market's most sophisticated traders. With the shares (ticker: DELL) trading at about 24, a popular anti-Dell trade was selling March 22.50 and 25 calls, betting that Dell's options prices will continue to decline, especially when Dell reports first-quarter earnings on March 1.   Indeed, in addition to the management change, Dell advised investors that earnings would fall short -- again. This suggests that Dell's implied volatility, the key determinant of equity options prices, also should decline in March on earnings news.   Yet just in case Michael Dell does something extraordinary that increases volatility, some of the skeptical traders who sold March calls also bought February 22.50 and 25 calls, essentially creating what one strategist described as a "volatility bull spread." Currently, Dell's three-month implied volatility is about 29%, compared with historic volatility of 27%.   At the moment, fundamental expectations for Dell are not particularly riveting. There is dissent among analysts, but restructurings are difficult to model and thus are best viewed with bearish assumptions, and just a little hope. Goldman Sachs' Laura Conigliaro advised clients in a research note that the stock can be expected to "do very little in the next couple of months, bottom in the low-$20s, and then start to gradually move higher based on anticipation of improving margins."   That is not quite the definition of "dead money," but it may be close, especially if Michael Dell uncovers issues that are more problematic than initially understood, by him and by investors.   The real upside to Dell may be Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), which many investors use as a point of comparison. Just as Dell's options prices are high, Hewlett-Packard's options prices are unusually low. HP's stock gained 39% during the past 12-months, and 121% over the past year.   The instinct for some traders will be to sell expensive Dell options and buy inexpensive Hewlett-Packard options, but very few traders, and perhaps only a handful of hedge funds, actually "pair trade" options.   The more prudent trade may be taking advantage of the unusual slump in Hewlett-Packard's options -- three-month volatility is 23%, near its one-year low -- to buy March 42.50 or 45 calls. The March options will capture Hewlett-Packard's Feb. 20 earnings report, and could increase if the stock is propelled higher by Dell's turnaround taking longer than expected.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: E.ON Can't Fund Endesa Bid With Debt If Tender Rate 100% -2-
Story: Late Friday, E.ON raised its takeover offer for Endesa by more than 12% to about EUR41 billion.   E.ON's sweetened offer - of EUR38.75 for each of Endesa's 1.059 billion outstanding shares - came one day after rival bidder Gas Natural SDG SA (GAS.MC) dropped its own cash-and-shares bid of about EUR24 billion, paving the way for the creation of Europe's largest power company.   In case 100% of Endesa share capital will be tendered to E.ON, the Duesseldorf-based company would likely try to identify possible asset disposals to help fund the deal, Schenck said in the analyst conference call.   However, any asset sale to help fund the Endesa takeover would be from E.ON's existing business portfolio, Chief Executive Wulf Bernotat said.   "We have said that we will keep Endesa's integrity  intact. So any asset sales would be from E.ON operations," Bernotat said.   Thereafter, if needed, E.ON has the option of possible financial measures, CFO Schenck said.   "But the final financing structure of the takeover depends on the final level of acceptances by Endesa shareholders," Schenck said.   E.ON's previous EUR36.5 billion offer for Endesa was financed with a EUR37.1 billion syndicated loan and guarantee facility, the world's largest ever of its kind, signed in October.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 09:28 ET (14:28 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Charles E. Scripps Dies at 87
Story: Long-time chairman of The E. W. Scripps Company was a visionary media pioneer       CINCINNATI, Feb. 3 /PRNewswire/ -- Charles E. Scripps, scion of a legendary media family and the board chairman of The E. W. Scripps Company (NYSE: SSP) for more than four decades, died today of natural causes at the age of 87 near his home in Naples, Fla.        (Photo:  http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20070203/NYSA014 )     Charles Scripps' long tenure as head of the company founded in 1878 by his grandfather, Edward W. Scripps, was marked by dramatic expansion into new businesses and impressive financial growth.     As board chairman from 1953 until 1994, he presided over the company's growth as a newspaper publisher and the company's entry into other forms of media, including broadcast television, cable TV systems, cable TV networks and the Internet. In 1986, the company brought cousin John P. Scripps' seven West Coast newspapers into the family fold with a merger agreement, and two years later initiated a public stock offering that provided family members with a way to diversify their holdings. Simultaneously, Scripps served as trustee of The Edward W. Scripps Trust -- controlling shareholder of the company -- and was chairman of the Trust from 1948 until 2004.     "To carry the family name is to carry the responsibility for quality and innovation in an ever-changing media environment," Scripps said in a 2003 interview. "The E.W. Scripps Company has survived 125 years because it embodies the entrepreneurial spirit of its founding father."     It was that spirit, which fostered development of Scripps Networks -- the division that operates HGTV, Food Network, DIY Network, Fine Living and GAC (Great American Country), of which Scripps was especially proud.     "This company, our community and the entire media industry are affected by the loss of Charles Scripps," said Kenneth W. Lowe, president and chief executive officer of The E. W. Scripps Company. "Charles set the tone for this company's fearless journalism, unquestioned integrity and restless innovation. Those are legacies that continue to influence our approach to operating the business that carries his family's name."     When once asked about a guiding principle, Scripps said, "It's simple, really. Just look at the direction you're going and ask: 'Can we be proud of that?'"     "Charles Scripps provided the glue that bonded the Scripps enterprise together for a half-century," said William R. Burleigh, chairman of The E. W. Scripps Company. "He stepped forward as the family's representative when he was only 28 and served continuously until 2003, presiding over a period of unprecedented growth and success. This sense of responsibility and wise counsel animated everything he did -- in the company, in his family and in the community."     Often described as "a newspaperman's newspaperman," Scripps regularly asked editors, "What are you doing for your communities?"     When the newspaper division was introducing its Total Quality program to news and business leaders in the late 1980s, Scripps was asked for a slogan. He responded with just three words: "Quality reflects character."     He later explained, "I remember getting a note from a disgruntled reader about an error in one of our newspapers. I checked it out and I was told it was 'just a minor error.' I remember saying that there's no such thing as a minor error. An error is an advertisement of poor workmanship and we simply can't tolerate that in our newspapers. To be in journalism is to be in the business of credibility."     Scripps was born Jan. 27, 1920, in San Diego, to Robert Paine and Margaret Culbertson Scripps. He and his three brothers and two sisters grew up at nearby Miramar, their grandfather Edward Willis Scripps' 2,000-acre ranch.     Scripps attended William & Mary College in Williamsburg, Va., but returned to California and entered Pomona College after his father -- the sole trustee of The Edward W. Scripps Trust -- died at age 42 in 1938. Shortly thereafter, Scripps began his newspaper career at his grandfather's first newspaper, The Cleveland Press, where he covered police and courts.     "He willingly rose to the responsibility inherent to his birthright," said Lawrence A. Leser, retired chairman and CEO of Scripps. "He learned the business from the bottom up, tutored by the men who had worked with his father."     Just as Scripps inherited his grandfather's passion for publishing, the two also shared a love of sailing. It came as no surprise when young Scripps enlisted with the U.S. Coast Guard during World War II. He was stationed in the Pacific and rose to the rank of lieutenant before returning to the family business after the war.     Scripps was 28 when he became chairman of the family trust and moved to Cincinnati, where the trust was headquartered. Even after he became chairman of The E. W. Scripps Company five years later, he continued to live in Cincinnati rather than move to company headquarters in New York City. In 1977, he welcomed corporate executives to Cincinnati, where the company has since been headquartered.     Recognizing that with leadership comes responsibility, Scripps used his influence to promote freedom of the press throughout the world. He served as president of the Inter-American Press Association in 1980 and president of its advisory council from 1981-82. During that time, he also traveled to Mexico, Austria and the Soviet Union in support of UNESCO's International Programme for the Development of Communication and to France for the World Press Freedom Committee.     Through the years he served on the boards of many organizations, both those related to the media industry as well as civic and public service organizations in Cincinnati and, in later years, in Naples, Fla., where he spent the winter months.     However, the nonprofit organization that received his greatest attention was The Salvation Army, which he served locally, nationally and internationally.     "Mr. Scripps was a gentle giant," said Maj. Kenneth Maynor, divisional commander of The Salvation Army. "He was warm, humble and gracious -- totally without pretense -- and yet he was world-renowned as an innovative, truly great leader. During his 30-plus years of service he was a revered partner in the ministry, whose wisdom was a blessing we did not take for granted."     Scripps received The William Booth Award in 1988 and the prestigious "Others Award" from The Greater Cincinnati Salvation Army. In addition, he has been honored by the National Jewish Hospital and Research Center in Denver and the American Advertising Foundation. In 1983, he received an honorary doctorate from Ohio University for his contributions to communications and his "championship of press freedom worldwide." In 1986, the Scripps Howard Foundation established the Charles E. Scripps Literacy Award in his honor.     The Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce presented its Great Living Cincinnatian Award to Scripps in February 2003. In accepting the honor, he said, "It's not about power. It's about influence and how you use that for the betterment of your community and the world."     After 57 years on the company's board of directors, Scripps retired in May 2003. Four months later, Scripps was presented with a framed copy of the resolution board members passed in honor of his service. It recognizes the family-friendly workplace he created, his vision for the company, faith in its leadership and "resolve to produce quality journalism that enlightened the populace, improved communities and defended the First Amendment."     He leaves his wife, Mary Elizabeth (Libby) Breslin Scripps, whom he married in 1993; four children: Charles E. Scripps, Jr., of Darby, Mont.; Marilyn Scripps Wade and Julia Scripps Heidt, both of Cincinnati; and Eaton Scripps, of Boulder, Colo.; two stepsons, Ben P. Breslin and Andrew W. Breslin; seven grandchildren and three step-grandchildren; two brothers: Robert P. Scripps, of Fredericksburg, Texas; and Sam Scripps of Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was preceded in death by his wife of 41 years, Lois Anne MacKay Scripps.    SOURCE  The E. W. Scripps Company       /CONTACT: Tim Stautberg of The E. W. Scripps Company, +1-513-977-3826, Stautberg@scripps.com      /Web site: http://www.scripps.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 16:58 ET (21:58 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(2/5) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from Jan. 25 through Jan. 31.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Lifetime Brands (LCUT)   Jove Partners believes LCUT would benefit from additional marketing and industry expertise on its board, and suggested individuals for consideration. The investor has engaged in discussions with Lifetime's management, board, and other shareholders about LCUT's operations, management, strategy, board composition and future plans. Jove originally acquired shares for investment because they were "undervalued and represented an attractive investment opportunity." Jove owns 700,000 shares (5.2% of total outstanding).     Adesa (KAR)   Royce & Associates, Adesa's largest shareholder, said it is not only disappointed in the acquisition price, but also in the auction process and certain potential conflicts of interest. Last month, Adesa agreed to be acquired by a private-equity group  for $27.85 a share in cash. The group also will assume $700 million of Adesa's debt. Royce believes $35 a share would be more in line with industry comparables. Royce & Assoc. holds 6,490,075 shares (7.22%).     Center Bancorp (CNBC)   Investor Lawrence Seidman sent a letter to the company calling its fourth-quarter earnings "pathetic." Seidman has been calling for Center Bancorp's chief executive to step down since Seidman's request to join the board was declined. Seidman said CEO John Davis should be held responsible for the company's "feeble performance." Seidman holds 1,218,840 shares (9.22%).     Feldman Mall Properties (FMP)   Mercury Real Estate Advisors reiterated its call for the sale of FMP and hiring of an investment banker to pursue the process. "The company continues to trade at a significant discount to its liquidation value," said Mercury. Mercury has received "numerous inquiries" from mall owners interested in exploring acquisition of FMP. Mercury holds 1.27 million shares (9.7%).     Triad Hospitals (TRI)   TPG-Axon Capital Management expects to nominate an alternative slate of five candidates for election as directors at the company's 2007 annual meeting. TPG-Axon has been evaluating a range of potential actions regarding the company, and is currently engaged in discussions with a number of potential candidates whom the investor is considering for nomination to the board. TPG-Axon currently holds about 7.81 million shares (8.87%).     Original Filings     Adams Golf (ADGO)   Investor John Gregory reported ownership of 1,210,500 shares (5.12%) after buying 988,701 from Nov. 6, 2006 to Jan. 26, 2007 at $1.44 to $2.04 apiece.     Increases in Holdings     DCAP Group (DCAP)   Infinity Capital Partners raised its holdings to 264,774 shares (9.14%) after buying 31,357 Jan. 5 to 26 at $2.92 to $3.01 each.     Decreases in Holdings     Paxar (PXR)   Blum Capital Partners cut its holdings to 1,884,411 shares (4.6%) after selling 691,100 from Dec. 5, 2006 to Jan. 30, 2007 at $21.94 to $22.15 a share.     ITT Educational Services (ESI)   A group including Blum Capital Partners reduced its position to 2,887,000 shares (7%), after it sold 968,130 from Dec. 7 to Jan. 29 at $67.00 to $76.82 apiece.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Plugged In: EMC Goes On The Offensive
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   It's been only six months since EMC bought security-token maker RSA, much to the chagrin of many investors, but the storage giant is determined to prove that it was a good move.   This week in San Francisco, EMC's RSA division will host the year's largest information-security convention, fittingly named the RSA Conference. And as part of RSA's coming-out party at EMC (ticker: EMC), its parent is expected to make announcements aimed at demonstrating that the two companies' integration is proceeding faster and more seamlessly than expected.   The headline grabber is likely to be the unveiling of a "mutual flagship product" that marries EMC's core storage technology with RSA's main security prowess: authentication. (Authentication is a way of proving you are who you say you are to a computer device.) EMC will unveil a line of its high-end Symmetrix storage arrays with RSA's advanced authentication technology built in, knowledgeable people say.   The key trend in information security is to protect access to information stored on a network. Corporations have rooms and rooms of data centers, the nerve centers of their computer networks. Numerous maintenance people and service providers need access to various components of a network, but only a select group needs access to the machines that store the data -- the storage arrays. The built-in authentication devices should provide an extra line of defense for precious information.   EMC officials are telling clients that they envision identity-authentication technology being imbedded in all kinds of appliances and products.   When EMC CEO Joe Tucci announced last July that he was buying RSA, critics cried that he was paying too much (five times sales) and that the security-token (portable authentication devices) business and storage were incompatible. Tucci argued that there's more to RSA than key-ring tokens. What's more, he added, not only is authentication integral to storage, but his customers were demanding that EMC provide it. The Street didn't buy his logic, hammering EMC shares to a July low of 9.44. Since then, they've rebounded to around 14, thanks largely to a strong December quarter.     Hello Dick? One has to wonder how long it took for Motorola's chief executive, Ed Zander, to ring up Time Warner (TWX) CEO Richard Parsons on his RAZR after discovering that Carl Icahn was now Moto's (MOT) problem. Parsons fended off Icahn's personal attacks, as well as his tireless attempts to break up the media conglomerate, so maybe he could give Zander some good advice.   After two disappointing quarters and a major margin malfunction, Zander is up to his eyeballs in crisis. Now Icahn, who's amassed a 1.4% stake in Motorola, is demanding that he use some of its $12 billion in cash to buy back more of its sagging shares. Plus, he wants a board seat. Motorola stock jumped 6.9% Tuesday, to 19.58, on news of the Icahn stake. Late Friday, it was trading at 19.82. "I don't think Zander will be keen on dumping Motorola's huge cash balance into a big stock-repurchase program," says Charter Equity analyst Ed Snyder, "but it will be a fight."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Microsoft's Game To Lose
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   The hoopla over the launch of Vista, microsoft's new Windows operating system for personal computuer, had been building up for months. Investors had been pumping up the stock and geeks had been downloading programs that counted the days, minutes and seconds to the magic moment. Come zero hour last Tuesday evening, the colossus of Redmond, Wash., celebrated with champagne and exotic dancers in New York's Times Square. Computer makers around the world bought into the happyparty, with 18 of them, Dell, Hewlett-Packard, Lenovo and Sony included, unveiling over 100 new desktops and laptops specifically designed to work with Vista.   On Wall Street, alas, the reaction was a big yawn. Microsoft's stock (ticker: MSFT) was little changed for the week, closing Friday at 30.19. The problem is that most of the excitement about Vista got baked into the stock price as it surged some 40% since last summer. While there could still be some upside left, the greatest potential for a price move is on the downside. If Vista, over time, fails to meet the market's high expectations, a good chunk of last year's gains could evaporate. In other words, Vista is now Microsoft's game to lose.   And a long game it could be: A meaningful verdict on Vista's success won't be in for months. Any upturn in PC upgrades will have to prove itself sustainable, and one of Microsoft's biggest claims about the system -- that it is unusually secure -- will have to hold up to persistent challenges by hackers. If they find holes, the world's view of Vista could darken quickly. Then there are the inevitable bugs in the system. The word on the Internet is that Microsoft already has a team, code named Fiji, working on the first corrective Vista Service Pack (SP1) to come out this fall. Microsoft wouldn't comment; the company's fans can only hope that service packs will be few and far between.   Though Vista has been available to corporations since November, the votes by chief information officers are still being counted. Microsoft has talked about "encouraging early demand," and a few major companies like Citigroup have formally committed to switch over from XP by the middle of 2007. Yet companies are unlikely to be early adopters in big numbers. None have an incentive to buy new for the sake of newness and many use in-house programs that will have to be adapted to run with Vista. And like everyone else, companies may want to wait until any weaknesses are discovered and repaired.   Little wonder that some savvy analysts aren't exactly dancing in Times Square. "Vista is an incremental step forward but, in the end, I don't think it alters PC buying habits and I don't think it spurs an upgrade cycle," says Brad Reback of CIBC. "While I feel that Microsoft management and the stock market are adopting a conservative outlook, and things could come in a bit better than generally expected, I don't think the scenario is very exciting."   As Microsoft's first new operating system since XP, Vista was five years, hundreds of thousands of man-hours and some $6 billion in the making. The result of all this, in the opinion of most reviewers, is only a moderately better mousetrap. As the chief gadget reviewer for Barron's, I would love to offer a firmly contrarian, upbeat view. But after testing Vista for four weeks on two computers, I have no choice but to join the legions of the ambivalent.   The look and feel of Vista is clearly different. The old hourglass icon that appeared during delays has been replaced by a gleaming, spinning blue circle. The cute names for standard folders, like "My Pictures" and "My Music," have been changed to simpler ones -- "Pictures" and "Music." Overall, the desktop is stunningly good to look at, with transparent windows removing much of the old clutter. Vista's Flip 3D feature allows you to view all your open windows at the same time in a sort of fanned out view that makes navigating between them a cinch.   Best of all, Microsoft has added a feature called Windows Sidebar, for running all sorts of mini-applications such as stock tickers, news headlines, weather forecasts and RSS readers with the latest from your favorite blog.     But I found Vista to be not all good news. Some of my gadgets, for instance, stopped talking to my desktop. Though my wireless keyboard and mouse, backup drive, wireless router and Canon All-In-One printer worked fine, my 18-month-old backup drive and two-year-old Sony Digital Photo Printer did not. And e-mails to Sony quickly revealed that the company has no plans to issue new Vista-compatible drivers, meaning I might as well now junk the printer.   My somewhat older laptop had trouble with Vista itself, never mind the gadgets. At a creaky 18 months old, it didn't have the power to run anything but basic Vista, and it did that in fits and starts and very slowly. Worst of all, when I tried to roll the machine back to XP, I discovered that, once you do a full upgrade, Vista cannot be uninstalled. All you can do is reformat the hard drive, lose all your data and programs and reinstall XP all over again. Seeking confirmation of this from the Microsoft Website, I discovered the company was at that point charging $245 per incident for a support call.   Microsoft does seem to have approached the security issue forcefully. So-called core codes have been written to prevent rogue software from taking over a computer, with a new sub-program called Windows Defender in theory keeping out viruses, spyware, Trojan horses, phishing attacks and other nasty intruders. But again, there's a real downside: Vista can drive you to distraction with warnings and red alerts every time you install a new program, download a file or change your system settings. Worse, though they're as yet unproven, several technoid Websites have claimed to have discovered gaps in Vista's defenses.   Though strictly speaking it is not part of Vista, the new Office 2007 software (which runs happily on XP machines) will for many be part of the Vista experience; they'll elect to trade up here at the same time. The fact is, the makeover from the old Word and Excel programs are much more obvious and in the end even more compelling than the change-up from XP.   Gone are the old drop-down menus and dialog boxes. In their place is a drastically new user-interface called the ribbon that organizes features into tabs. Click on Home in Word, for example, and it reveals the ribbon with font types and sizes, the highlighting crayon, paragraph settings and different pre-set styles. Click on Insert and it replaces that ribbon with one allowing you to paste in anything from a picture to a chart or signature. Just be warned: Word saves documents in a format that isn't automatically opened by previous versions of the program, meaning colleagues who haven't upgraded may be flumoxed by your e-mail Word attachments.     So, how might all this play out as a business for Microsoft? For the next six months and maybe longer, the main demand for Vista will come from ordinary home computer users. With 665 million versions of XP and a further 190 million older versions of Windows installed worldwide (giving Microsoft a 96% share of the market, according to Gartner Dataquest), some number of users obviously will upgrade. But probably not too many. For one thing, Vista isn't cheap -- $100 for the basic upgrade, at least $250 for the Ultimate. And older PCs simply lack the horsepower to run Vista. Most Vista sales, then, will be to computer makers, who will pre-load it on their new machines.   And that brings us to the question of whether Vista will spark the long-awaited upgrade cycle. Was last year's weakness in PC sales indicative of people waiting for Vista, and will its appeal now be enough to persuade millions of computer users to spring for a new machine?   The world's PC makers, faced with relatively lackluster sales and fierce competition, are praying it will. To that end they have come out with new, powerful laptops and desktops, even while heavily discounting their less capable XP-based models.   Just last week, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ), Dell (DELL), Gateway (GTW), Sony (SNE) and Toshiba (6502.Japan) all announced either new or refreshed models in support of the Vista launch. Some of the new machines cost as little as $600 and can run the basic version of the software, but most carry prices above $2,500 and include the huge hard drives and memories required to make the most of Vista.   Dell, for one, insists that it is benefitting from Vista mania. It says that during the weekend before the launch, it registered a 20% increase in the number of visitors logging into the company's Website over the weekend before. It said it "sold tens of thousands of Vista-equipped machines."   While those aren't the kind of hard numbers a bull might want, enough good things are happening at Microsoft that the stock still does have its bulls. In fact, the Street sees the company's earnings jumping 38% in the first two quarters of 2007, the final half of its fiscal year, and a further 16% over the following 12 months. That leaves the stock trading at a reasonable 20.5 times earnings for the current fiscal year.   "Yes, there certainly is potential for a backlash" if consumers and investors are disappointed by Vista, says longtime Microsoft watcher Rick Sherlund of Goldman Sachs. "But Vista excels at the sort of glitz interface that people like and, even if there is no compelling reason for upgrading, there is a reason. . . . It's sort of like your older car works fine but you still want a new cool model. I think demand will be higher than expected, that PC sales growth will top the industry's 8%-10% expectation and Vista will be a success. My target for the stock is 36."   Investors, however, have to weigh such views against the real threat of the stock falling every bit as much or further -- to 24 or lower. You don't need an upgraded Excel program to know how that would hurt.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : ADP Announces Digital Marketing Suite of E-Business Solutions
Story: - A new suite of services helps dealers create more traffic, drive more leads, close additional sales and keep more customers -       HOFFMAN ESTATES, Ill., Feb. 3 /PRNewswire/ -- The Dealer Services Group of Automatic Data Processing Inc. (NYSE: ADP) today announced the launch of its Digital Marketing suite of solutions.  ADP's Digital Marketing solutions enable automotive dealerships to maximize the power of digital direct marketing.  The suite includes solutions for:          --  Digitally marketing every profit center in the dealership      --  Maximizing search engine placement to generate more qualified organic          leads      --  Customer communication tools to follow up and close more sales          opportunities       ADP's Digital Marketing solutions enable dealerships to communicate with their prospects and customers through several electronic channels including email, text messages, automated voice and the dealership Web site itself.  ADP Digital Marketing also offers the choice of highly automated marketing solutions, outsourced customer communications or providing the dealership with the digital marketing tools they need to execute their own marketing strategy.          With ADP's Digital Marketing solutions dealerships are able to:      --  Generate more leads      --  Convert a higher percentage of leads to sales      --  Reduce the cost of generating leads      --  Increase front-end gross       "Recognizing the tremendous opportunities Digital Marketing offers our customers, we are excited to introduce ADP's Digital Marketing suite of solutions that is especially designed for automotive dealerships," said Kevin Henahan, senior vice president of marketing for ADP Dealer Services.  "This suite of e-Business solutions will make it easy for dealers to drive new traffic, obtain more leads and seamlessly manage those leads whether they come from their Web site, their phone or their showroom.  As part of our fully-integrated front-end solutions, ADP's Digital Marketing solutions help dealers easily and cost-effectively drive incremental revenue, solidify customer relationships and reduce advertising expense while generating higher returns."     A key piece of ADP's Digital Marketing suite is its Search Engine Marketing solution.  Search Engine Marketing drives measurable increases in high-quality organic sales lead traffic while reducing overall marketing costs.  Search Engine Marketing ensures prominent placement for the most relevant search phrases used by car buyers.     ADP's Digital Marketing solutions also make it easy for dealers to publish and market their vehicle inventory in the online consumer portals in which they market themselves in a secure way, without requiring third parties to access their system.  Inventory can be marketed with high-impact slide shows or audio or video presentations including interior and exterior photos. Easy-to-use online auction management tools enable dealers to easily and quickly publish highly attractive placements of their inventory and sell their new and pre-owned vehicles on e-Bay(R) Motors.        About ADP Dealer Services     ADP Dealer Services provides integrated computing solutions to nearly 25,500 auto, truck, motorcycle, marine and recreational vehicle dealers throughout the United States, Canada, Asia, China, Europe and the Middle East. ADP Dealer Services is a business unit of Automatic Data Processing, Inc. (NYSE: ADP).  ADP, with nearly $9 billion in revenues and more than 570,000 clients worldwide, is one of the largest providers of a broad range of premier, mission-critical, cost-effective transaction processing and information-based business solutions.  More information on ADP Dealer Services is available on the Internet at http://www.dealersuite.com.    SOURCE  ADP Dealer Services       /CONTACT: Doug Towle of ADP Dealer Services, +1-847-485-4374, doug_towle@adp.com      /Web site: http://www.dealersuite.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 09:00 ET (14:00 GMT)

Headline: : DealerTrack Launches InventoryPro, Next Generation Inventory Management Solution
Story: InventoryPro is the foundation of DealerTrack's strategy to provide dealers with a comprehensive inventory management solution       LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Feb. 3 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- DealerTrack, Inc., a subsidiary of DealerTrack Holdings, Inc. (Nasdaq: TRAK), today announced the introduction of InventoryPro, a new inventory management solution for auto dealers.     InventoryPro will empower dealers, leveraging their valuable knowledge and expertise with analytical tools that manage inventory turnover through the use of dealers' specific sales history, as well as market data. Resulting recommendations enable dealers to take control of their inventory and stock more of the vehicles that turn faster and generate higher gross profits, while quickly disposing of those that are less profitable. Additionally, InventoryPro will provide dealers with a broad range of tools to appraise and book out their inventory, integrating values from Manheim Market Report(TM) (MMR), N.A.D.A.(R), Black Book(R) and Kelley Blue Book(R).     Mark O'Neil, DealerTrack's chairman and CEO, said, "With the continued market pressure on for new vehicle sales, we believe dealers are placing a growing premium on maximizing the profitability of their used vehicle operations. Systematic inventory management, based on industry data as well as the dealerships' own sales and profitability records, should increase inventory turns and deliver dealers much needed improvement in profitability."     With the launch of InventoryPro, DealerTrack begins the introduction of its comprehensive inventory solution. Throughout the year a series of products and services are expected to be deployed to further enhance dealers' inventory needs, including:          -- Integration with Chrome's ADS (Automotive Description Service) which         will give dealers the ability to deliver more accurate and         comprehensive vehicle descriptions than the VIN decoder products         currently on the market.      -- An inventory exchange that will provide dealers with a single point of         access to inventory on a real-time basis from various auctions,         including Manheim and a variety of ATC-Onlane hosted wholesale auction         websites (including ATC Open).      -- Inventory Management and Analytical tools through InventoryPro.      -- ALG pricing and market data as well as content from Chrome.       All of these capabilities will be provided as part of the DealerTrack suite of products, allowing dealers to leverage a single platform delivering unparalleled value.     "We are pleased to partner with DealerTrack to provide the Manheim Market Report to dealerships across the country," said Lynn Morgan, Vice President of Manheim Consulting. "InventoryPro is another opportunity for our organizations to broaden the services provided to dealers to help them gain more control over their inventory costs."     DealerTrack's main objective is to provide dealers a way to manage all of their inventory needs in one place and create a marketplace for dealers to buy and sell inventory in a real-time environment.     InventoryPro will be easy to use and features enhanced functionality, including best-in-class vehicle appraisal capabilities. InventoryPro will also be integrated with other DealerTrack sales and F&I solutions, enabling dealers to take a vehicle from inventory to structuring, financing and funding a deal -- in one seamless, paperless process.     InventoryPro replaces DealerTrack's DealerWire(R) solution, which was acquired last year and will be phased out as subscribers are transitioned to the new product at no additional charge        About DealerTrack (www.dealertrack.com)     DealerTrack (Nasdaq: TRAK) is a leading provider of on-demand software and data solutions for the U.S. automotive retail industry. The company's online credit application processing product automates and accelerates the automotive financing process, while its integrated subscription-based software enables dealers to receive consumer leads, compare financing and leasing options, sell insurance and other aftermarket products, document compliance, and execute financing contracts electronically. Over 22,000 dealers, with more than 85% of all franchised dealers; over 300 financing sources, including nine captives and the 20 largest U.S. independents; and other service and information providers are active in the DealerTrack network.        Safe Harbor for Forward-Looking and Cautionary Statements     Statements in this press release regarding DealerTrack, the features and benefits of InventoryPro, future inventory solution products and services, and all other statements in this release other than the recitation of historical facts are forward-looking statements (as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995). These statements involve a number of risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results, performance or achievements of DealerTrack Holdings, Inc. to be materially different from any future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by these forward-looking statements.     Factors that might cause such a difference include: increased competitive pressure from other industry participants, the inability to execute any element of DealerTrack's business strategy, including the retention of dealers and aftermarket provider customers; selling additional products and services to existing and new customers; success in expanding our customer base and product and service offerings and integrating acquisitions; and other risks listed in our reports filed with the SEC, including our Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2005. These filings can be found at www.dealertrack.com and the SEC's website at www.sec.gov. Forward-looking statements included herein speak only as of the date hereof and we disclaim any obligation to revise or update such statements to reflect events or circumstances after the date hereof or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events or circumstances.          CONTACT:      Greg Slote      DealerTrack      (516) 734-3921      greg.slote@dealertrack.com        Tom Pratt      RFBinder Partners      (212) 994-7563      tom.pratt@rfbinder.com      SOURCE  DealerTrack, Inc.       /CONTACT: Greg Slote of DealerTrack, +1-516-734-3921, or greg.slote@dealertrack.com; or Tom Pratt of RFBinder Partners, +1-212-994-7563, or tom.pratt@rfbinder.com, for DealerTrack, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 11:00 ET (16:00 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Other Voices: Someone May Be Gaining On Us
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Harold L. Sirkin   One of the advantages of youth is that the young don't know what they don't know. While a savvy veteran might abandon a project when obstacles arise, the novice will soldier on, and sometimes get the job done, despite the odds. This may be one of the most important advantages that companies from rapidly developing economies have as they strive to become global leaders. They don't know what they don't know, but there's a lot they do know.   I joined several colleagues from Boston Consulting Group offices in Beijing, Boston, Moscow, New Delhi, Paris and Sao Paulo recently to examine about 3,000 companies from rapidly developing economies (RDE). We identified 100 companies that are positioning themselves to challenge today's leaders. They are headquartered in, among other places, Brazil, China, Egypt, India, Malaysia, Mexico, Russia, Thailand and Turkey, and we call them the BCG RDE 100. Many are relatively unknown. But any could become a new global power.   All together in 2004, the 100 companies accounted for $715 billion in revenue (the total should hit $1 trillion this year) and $145 billion in operating profit. That produced a 20% profit margin, compared with 16% for companies in the Standard & Poor's 500, 10% for those in Japan's Nikkei and 9% for those in Germany's DAX.   Some 28% of the RDE 100's revenue, about $200 billion in 2004, came from international sales. The companies grew 24% a year from 2000 through 2004, which is 10 times faster than the U.S. gross domestic product, 24 times Japan's rate of growth and 34 times Germany's.   The majority of the rising companies we analyzed are in industries where U.S. companies are no longer the dominant players, such as automotive equipment, shipping, textiles and consumer electronics. But many challengers are in industries -- aerospace, petrochemicals, engineered products, engineering services and pharmaceuticals, for example -- where U.S. firms hold commanding positions and hope to maintain those positions well into the future.   While U.S., European and Japanese companies still enjoy certain advantages -- brand identity and loyalty, patent and trademark protection, longstanding traditions of innovation, and established distribution channels  -- most of the 100 newcomers are cash-rich and ready to exploit advantages of their own, and not merely their low-cost labor and value-priced products.   The challengers know how to market and sell profitably to low-income customers. They know how to deal with immature logistics and distribution networks. They know how to navigate ambiguous legal environments. They know how to manage successfully, despite shortages of management talent. And, in most cases, they have developed the ability to innovate quickly and make very rapid decisions. These qualities -- as much as the well-documented advantages they enjoy as a result of significantly lower labor, capital and raw-material costs -- will serve them well as they look beyond their home markets and prepare to go head-to-head with current leaders.   Just as many of today's most prominent Japanese and South Korean companies were largely unknown to, or denigrated by, their U.S. and European competitors in the 1960s and '70s, many of our 100 companies still operate in relative obscurity.   China's Guangdong Galanz Enterprises, for example -- a name unfamiliar to most Americans -- commands 45% of the microwave market in Europe and 25% in the United States. But the Galanz brand is rare at U.S. retail stores. Most of the microwave ovens the company makes for the U.S. market are produced for other companies that put their own logos on them.   However, 28 of the 100 companies we studied are growing internationally by taking their established home-market products and brands to global markets.   Hisense, a $3.3 billion consumer-electronics firm, is one of China's premier makers of TV sets (with an 11% share of the domestic market), air conditioners, refrigerators, PCs and telecom equipment. Hisense also manufactures in Algeria, Hungary, Iran, Pakistan and South Africa. To meet China's fast-moving and highly demanding consumer-electronics market, Hisense has developed a world-class research-and-development operration -- with about 20 specialized research centers and institutes -- to go with its super-scale, low-cost manufacturing base.   The company produces a continuous stream of new items. It currently sells roughly 10 million TV sets and 3 million air conditioners annually in more than 40 countries, with international sales accounting for $490 million, or 15%, of total revenue. In the United States, Best Buy, Kohl's and Micro Center computer stores all carry Hisense wares.   Representative of the companies basing their growth on strong R&D is Wipro Technologies, the Indian IT-services group. Wipro's revenue has expanded from $545 million in 2000 to $2.4 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, 2006. The company's competitive strength isn't just cost, but its ability to completely redesign customers' business processes.   Globalization is entering a new phase. Companies unknown to many Western consumers and executives -- food and beverage outfits like Thailand's Charoen Pokphand Foods and Mexico's Femsa, appliance makers such as China's Gree Electric Appliances and Turkey's Koc Holding, consumer-electronics producers like China's Hisense and Konka Group and India's Videocon Industries -- are getting set to go for the gold.   U.S. and other Western companies need to take the RDE challengers seriously. Remember: The advantages of youth mean that the challengers don't know that their processes and products can't compete with the reigning global leaders'. And if these leaders repeat the mistakes of the past, they'll find themselves playing catch-up some day, as many U.S. and European auto makers are today.   ---   HAROLD L. SIRKIN, is senior vice president of The Boston Consulting Group and head of its global operations practice. He is co-author, with James P. Andrew, of Payback: Reaping the Rewards of Innovation, published by Harvard Business School Press.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Follow-Up: Paulsen Sees Big Rally And More Risk
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   While most stock-market forecasters expect only a tepid rise in U.S. stocks this year, Wells Capital Management strategist James Paulsen sees an impending melt-up -- in which stock prices rise sharply over the next two to three quarters, before possibly suffering a nasty fall.   Talk is cheap, of course. Yet Paulsen has credibility, since he's among the few forecasters who early on smelled out the U.S. economic recovery and bull market that began in late 2002. He has articulated his views in several Barron's interviews, most recently for the Oct. 23, 2006, issue ("Reluctant Rally Still Has Life").   His case for a new bull run in stocks -- which could eclipse 2006's gains -- revolves around both the large amount and persistence of liquidity in the U.S. and around the globe that's increasingly seeking out riskier assets like equities. Normally, one would've expected this cash to have dried up after five years of economic recovery and 21/2 years of Fed monetary tightening. But U.S. bond yields and credit-market risk spreads remain near historic lows, and stocks the world over remain in solid uptrends.   What Paulsen dubs the "super-liquidity" cycle of the current recovery has unique antecedents. Mostly, it's a result of excessive Fed monetary stimulation that occurred earlier in the decade in reaction to the dot-com meltdown, the 9/11 terror attacks and fear in 2003 that the U.S. might sink into the same deflationary abyss as the one that engulfed Japan.   Only this time, the Fed-manufactured liquidity surge became a global phenomenon because China and other emerging nations pegged their currencies to the U.S. dollar. China today has more than $1 trillion worth of foreign-currency reserves, a large portion of them in dollars.   Meanwhile, says Paulsen, U.S. households are also loaded with cash and enjoying record net worth, despite the much-ballyhooed pricking of the real-estate bubble.   Yet for the first time in a long while, Paulsen is also sounding a cautionary note. He points out some unsettling parallels between the period leading up to the 1987 crash and today. Then, as now, the dollar had been sliding for several years and long-term bond rates were near record lows. Stocks, of course, took off in 1987, rising some 40% by Labor Day before collapsing that fall.   Does a replay loom? Paulsen isn't sure. But today's late-cycle surge in liquidity certainly portends a possible recrudescence in inflation, overheated economic growth and a rise in long-term rates that could trigger an end to global economic expansion and the current bull market -- particularly if a speculative frenzy sends stocks sharply higher in the months ahead, as Paulsen expects.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/5) Best Of The Best -2-
Story: Among the themes that worked for the fund were large-cap media and telecom. Good performers included Time Warner (TWX) and Comcast. Mike Embler, one of the fund's managers and the chief investment officer at Mutual Series, sees value in large-cap names, such as Microsoft (MSFT) and Verizon (VZ).   Rounding out the top 10 for one year were No. 6 SEI Group, followed by TIAA-CREF, State Farm, Janus and Vanguard.   State Farm placed first in the general-stock category, thanks partly to the strong performance of State Farm Growth (STFGX), up nearly 17.4% on an adjusted basis. That fund, however, isn't available to the general public.   Janus came in ninth, helped by a very strong finish in general equity, after taking a drubbing in the early part of this decade. "The group has gone through hell and back and stayed largely intact, and now has all of these shared experiences," explains Scott Schoelzel, who runs Janus Twenty (JAVLX). That fund, closed to new investors, had a return of 12.3%, placing it at the pinnacle of its peer group.   At the spectrum's other end was Touchstone. Its dead-last showing among the 67 fund firms was largely a product of underperformance by its largest funds, including Touchstone Large Cap Growth (TEQAX), which lost 3.6% last year.   "The results were primarily attributable to the negative effects from specific security selection," said James H. Grifo, president of Touchstone Investments, in a prepared statement, adding that the funds' longer-term results are much better.   Calvert, which runs socially responsible funds, was second-to-last in the one-year ranking. In a statement, its chief investment officer for equities, Steve Falci, linked the results to "style and sector performance 'headwinds' that adversely affected our domestic-equities funds."   It didn't help, either, that the funds tended to tilt toward growth sectors, which were out of favor, compared to value sectors.   Calvert and other fund families are hoping that the growth ship finally arrives in 2007, after many years of false sightings.   ---   How We Analyzed The Families     Each fund's returns are adjusted for 12b-1 fees, which are used for marketing anddistribution expenses. The fees are added back into the returns. The aim is to measure the manager's skill.   Fund loads, or sales charges, aren't included in the calculation of returns, either. Each fund's return is measured against those of all funds in its Lipper category-large-cap value, for example. That leads to a percentile ranking, with 100 the best and 1 the lowest, which is then weighted by asset size, relative to the fund family's other assets in its general classification-world equity, for instance. If a family's biggest funds do well, that boosts its overall ranking.   Finally, the score is multiplied by the weighting of its general classification, such as world equity, as determined by the entire Lipper universe of funds. The category weightings for the one-year results: general equity, 51.4%; world equity, 16.2%; mixed equity, 14.5%; taxable bond, 14.6%; tax-exempt bond, 3.2%.   The scoring: Say a company has a fund in the general U.S. equity category with $50 million, or half, of its assets in that category. Its ranking is the 75th percentile. The first calculation would be 75 x 0.50, which comes to 37.5. That score is then multiplied by 51.4%, general equity's overall weighting in Lipper's universe. So it would be 37.5 x 0.514, which totals 19.3. Similar calculations are done for every fund in our study. Then, all the numbers are added up for a total score. The fund shop with the highest score wins, both for each category and overall.   In a departure last year, Barron's used return, not percentile, as the basis for the ranking. We've decided to go back to our traditional metric.   -- L.C.S.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UAE Taqa Completes $694M Acquisition Of BP Dutch E&P Arm
Story: DUBAI (Dow Jones)--Abu Dhabi National Energy Co. (TAQA.AD), or Taqa, said Saturday it has completed the $694-million acquisition of BP Netherlands gas exploration and production assets, which will now be known as Taqa Energy B.V.   Taqa announced its intention to acquire BP Nederland Energie B.V., the Dutch arm of BP PLC (BP.IN) in late 2006 . It's now the majority shareholder and operator of the Dutch gas activities, comprising onshore and offshore production assets, including the Piek Gas Installatie facility in Alkmaar.   "By assuming control of an existing operation with significant interests in the upstream, midstream and downstream businesses, Taqa has positioned itself well at the center of the 'Energy Roundabout' of Europe, ideally located between Europe's two main demand centers - the U.K. and Germany," said Peter Barker-Homek, Taqa's chief executive.   The operation also consists of gas storage facilities at the Bergermeer field in the Netherlands, linking Dutch and British gas hubs.   Taqa is developing the world's first offshore liquefied natural gas regasification facility, utilizing the depleted field P15/P18, just off the port of Rotterdam, the press release said.   The company expects to be able to provide LNG Regas at a cost below EUR0.3 per million British thermal units, attracting LNG producers and targeting the U.K. and European markets, said the press release.   The BP E&P business had net production of around 62 million cubic feet a day in 2005.   Taqa, majority owned by the Abu Dhabi government, has invested in several energy-related areas such as power generation, desalination, renewables, upstream oil and gas, refining/retail and pipelines.   The company is building up its position in Europe. It recently acquired Talisman Energy's (TLM.T) Brae assets in the U.K for $550 million. Last year it bought a stake in Russia's state-run oil and gas major Rosneft (ROSN.RS) and in a unit of Electricite de France (1024251.FR).   -By Ayesha Daya, Dow Jones Newswires; +971 4 2279520; ayesha.daya@dowjones.com   Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 03, 2007 08:29 ET (13:29 GMT)

Headline: Rumors Swirling About Location Of Toyota's Next US Plant
Story: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. (AP)--Rumors are swirling that Toyota Motor Corp. (TM) is close to making an announcement about where it will build its next U.S. assembly plant.   But if a decision is coming soon, nobody's talking.   "We are actively looking at sites," said Dan Sieger, a spokesman for Japan's top automaker, and that's the most anyone at Toyota would say.   Competition is fierce since the assembly plant would create at least 2,000 new jobs. Newspapers have reported that Chattanooga is a finalist, along with Marion, Ark., which is near Memphis.   The Wall Street Journal, citing anonymous sources, also mentioned Chattanooga and Marion, along with Alamo, Tenn., and Davidson County, N.C.   But Chattanooga's mayor, Tennessee's governor and the state's top industry recruiter won't say anything specific about the Toyota plant.   Officials in Chattanooga already have a 1,600-acre industrial site ready, and they have a contract with the law firm of Howard Baker, the former U.S. senator and ambassador to Japan, to help with economic development. Baker would not comment.   Beyond the 2,000 jobs, the Toyota plant could make an even bigger employment ripple, with an indirect impact of about 10,000 jobs, according to studies by the Center for Automotive Research in Ann Arbor, Mich.   Michael Randle, editor and publisher of Southern Business and Development magazine in Birmingham, Ala., said he has correctly predicted most auto assembly plant sites, starting with BMW in South Carolina in 1992. He is not ruling out Chattanooga, but he guesses Toyota will pick Marion, Ark., this time.   Randle said no Japanese auto company has ever located a new plant on a redeveloped former industrial site, also known as a "brownfield" location.   The Chattanooga site is on land that was part of a former Army TNT plant complex, with ammunition bunkers that have been removed. The TNT plant shut down in 1977 and the Army cleaned up explosives, metals and PCBs in the soil and groundwater.   "It's not a slam on Chattanooga," Randle said. "I just don't think it's going to be an automotive plant."   Tennessee Department of Environment and Conservation spokeswoman Tisha Calabrese-Benton said the Chattanooga site was never categorized as a brownfield.   She said some cleanup work was done at the site to remove limited areas of contamination. "The site has been investigated, cleared and is clean to a residential standard," she said.   Hamilton County Mayor Claude Ramsey also said the Chattanooga site had been tested by state and federal officials and was "clean and ready to be used."   "We even have insurance if something is found," Ramsey said.   Sieger, the Toyota spokesman, said that in the two decades since the company started building plants in the U.S., all of them had been on "greenfield" sites, land that was either agricultural or undeveloped.   "Whether a site is a greenfield or brownfield is something we look at. It is a factor," Sieger said. "But by no means is it an absolute prerequisite for a decision."   Steven Szakaly, an economist at the Center for Automotive Research, said auto companies prefer greenfield sites because there is usually plenty of nearby space for suppliers.   The new assembly plant would continue the trend of Japanese automakers moving manufacturing to the Southeastern U.S., where labor costs remain low.   Gov. Phil Bredesen has said repeatedly that Tennessee is working hard to recruit automotive industries, and Nissan Motor Co. (NSANY) recently moved its North American headquarters from California to the Nashville area.   Toyota has continued to grab market share and in 2006 passed DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX) as the No. 3 auto seller in the U.S. for the first time during a full calendar year. Analysts predict Toyota will likely knock Ford Motor Co.
